reviews.review_title: Sorry, but not as bad as claimed
reviews.content: This movie is aimed at children, and my daughter enjoyed it a lot. While the movie wasn't great or even really good for an adult, it was nowhere close to as bad as Angry Birds or Boss Baby. I expect it to be worse than most of the non-Disney, non-Pixar stuff. I saw one reviewer compare it unfavorably to Wreck it Ralph and Inside Out, but come on, why is that comparison even being made? Those are GREAT movies in their genre. This is a 5. It held my attention without irritating me, while my 4 year old enjoyed herself. Jokes didn't all hit, but the inside the phone software metaphors was more on the mark than the vast majority of live action portrayals of virtual worlds. Frankly I think the script needed maybe a couple more rounds of rewrites and it would have been above average.

I watched this movie before I have even heard or read any critic reviews or ratings about it. So I walked into the cinema with an open mind and high expectations.
And wouldn't you know it, I was severely disappointed at this movie. The movie struggled so hard to create funny moments which turned out to be cringy attempts at humor (especially the dance sequence).
Don't get me wrong, I was impressed by the great animation, and that's the only good thing about this movie. I feel sorry for the animators who have put in so much effort into this junk of a movie.
I feel like I shoudn't even call this a movie or a film. The Emoji Movie feels like an 86-minute advertisement with bland, cheesy, cringy dialogue and lazy writing. Other animated movies (for example the How to Train Your Dragon trilogy and the Toy Story trilogy) in comparison have so much more effort put into them.
"But this is made for children! You're over-analysing it!"
So are you saying that we shouldn't judge children films? Are you saying that every single movie made for children is great/perfect? According to this logic, Food Fight and Cool Cat Saves the Kids deserve 10/10, don't they? The target demographic of this movie does not, and will not, affect the fact that this movie is horrible. I'm so tired of hearing this excuse.
By the way, if you say that this is the best movie you have ever watched, you're paid by Sony or the director of this movie to write a positive review, or you're sarcastic, or this is the only film you have ever watched. Go watch the How to Train Your Dragon trilogy, Toy Story trilogy and others and see if they change your mind.
Overall, the only positive aspect of this 'movie' is it's animation, but i's quickly overwhelmed by the negative aspects (writing, plot, characters, development, etc.).
The animation brought this movie from 0/10 to 1/10, and that's about it.

reviews.review_title: It's JUST as bad as the trailers and premise make it out to be
reviews.content: The Emoji Movie...boy am I embarrassed to have seen this thing. This movie essentially has an A and B plot that work off each other. The A plot is about a 'meh' emoji named Gene who is able to make multiple other expressions. When working at the cube, he messes up terribly by making a face other than a 'meh'. With his new friend Hi-5 and a hacker named Jailbreak, they must find a way to transform him into a 'normal' emoji by journeying through the smartphone. The B plot revolves around a freshman named Alex who tries to get the attention of Addie McCallister by sending her emojis...When I first found out about this movie I thought it was a joke. I just thought it was an April Fools Day prank pulled by Sony, but when the trailer for this movie arose in December, I feared for the worst...I don't even know where to begin. Let's start with the A plot. You may notice that it sounds really familiar, and it does. It sounds like the plot of Wreck-It Ralph. Just from the second trailer I knew that we would get a Wreck-It Ralph vibe. That's essentially what the concept of the A plot is. It's like they took the concept of warping from world to world presented in that movie and put it in a smartphone. The movie doesn't even go in-depth into what Gene's condition is. It just tells you that Gene can express multiple emotions and expect you to roll with it. All that does is bring analytic viewers to question the ideas of the movie. When it comes to the A plot though, it's just linear, predictable and unpleasant to sit through.Hi-5 is a pointless character. All he does is act as the comic relief, and he even fails at that, as he didn't make me laugh once throughout the picture. The jokes in this movie are all cringeworthy. None of them hit. There were kids in the theater who hardly laughed at all, that's how bad these jokes were. There was only one joke that made me laugh and even that one will eventually become dated.The product placement is incredibly annoying. Throughout the movie we see many different real world apps like YouTube, Facebook, Instagram and even Candy Crush. I just felt cheap looking at these and many parts of the movie felt like advertisements for smartphone apps. They even try to be "cool and hip" with the kids. There is modern slang usage, movie references and even references to songs that went viral two to three years ago. For example, they play the Nae Nae song by Silento in hopes that kids in the audience can relate. You're not relating to your audience, you're pandering to them. It's not like in Wreck-It Ralph, for instance, where they bring in classic video game icons for viewers to relate to. The difference of bringing these different products in is that the classic video game icons are timeless, while the Nae Nae song became dated.There's also a sub-plot that I won't spoil that feels so pointless, and I say this for two reasons. One, the movie only cuts to that part twice. Second, the characters involved in said plot point don't get anywhere new.As for the B plot, it's probably the best part of this entire film, which isn't saying anything. The characters outside the smartphone are boring, but at least they're not annoying like the emojis. The animation for those scenes looks pretty good for the most part. Even saying that the B plot is the best part isn't saying much. Even the way that plot ends feels predictable.If you are a kid who is really into emojis, chances are that you will enjoy this film. Even at that, I don't think anyone else would enjoy it, just small kids to early teenagers. It's a terrible animated feature that's down there with Norm of the North that's unfunny, linear, empty, full of product placement and is just awful.2/10
It's stupid and I hate and I'd rather pour my milk before my cereal instead of watching this again
It's hard to overstate how bad this is. A stellar comedic cast and any one of them could have created a better movie if it was just 90 minutes of them reading the phone book.Do not ever watch this!
The movie's message is that communication among people is failing and can only be saved by texting with more emojis.How about face to face conversations?

Hoping to see any redeeming qualities of this movie's very negative buzz, can't say I was able to when I did. The animation quality, visual setting, and adding a few real-life app names looks inviting on the outside, but upon entering its world and inner workings, it was a waste and abysmal to take seriously as a "movie." As though it poorly replicated Pixar's Inside Out concept crossed with the technological theme of Disney's Wreck-It Ralph.I've seen plenty of animated features as both a kid and as an adult, but this is one you'd probably not want to see at a movie theater. It's pretty much a desperate, by-the-numbers cash grab done by all things Sony Animation, who had produced a few SO much better animated titles in the past.In the city of Textopolis, an emoji called Gene (T.J. Miller) is designed to be like his parents (both "meh" icons), but for some reason he has multiple ways of expressing himself in the smartphone of young teen Alex that it confuses those around him and his own user. Hoping to find his place, he goes on an adventure with female emoji hacker Jailbreak (Anna Faris) to have a true purpose in his user's data space.Director Tony Leondis said he was greatly inspired by Toy Story's concept, but his approach in using that for emojis doesn't work if the story squanders it with a predictable ending and difficult-to-like, cardboard characters. Other films that used the concept like say, Wreck-It Ralph and The LEGO Movie had a premise and morals that weren't questionable or inane. No. Instead, those movies emitted both the mythos and pathos in an intriguing and creative way. I don't blame the movie's voice cast at all for this mistake, it's the "story" that was unoriginal and a hodgepodge, including jokes that were too juvenile to find as funny.Overall, this'll attract the littler ones, but this flick is best suited as direct-to-DVD, not theater worthy.

reviews.review_title: you people need a sense of humor
reviews.content: OK I went in expecting the absolute worst from this movie as I was purchasing my ticket however as I got sat down I began to reolise all my worries were for nothing I really liked the movie it kept me entertained I don't know what the hell most of America saw but I laughed out loud more than once and my fave emoji was the badass jailbreak I say take the family go by yourself just ignore the critics and see this movie

reviews.review_title: A incomprehensible waste of money, work and talent
reviews.content:
When I first read the news that there is an animated full-length feature film being developed called "The Emoji Movie", I took my hand and forcefully applied it to my forehead. This movie was absolutely uncalled for, yes, we do live in a generation where everyone has a phone or computer and sends each other instant messages, sometimes adding emoticons to reflect their state, but that doesn't justify the need for it. What made sense to pour out $50 million into making this picture? And how come it ended up making over $250 million at the box office? It's beyond comprehension...."The Emoji Movie" centers on a city called Textopolis, which is basically in everyone's smartphone, and the residents of Textopolis are various emojis that have a daily job of making faces and emotions whenever the phone user selects one of them in a text message.The main character is Gene Meh, a..."Meh" emoji that doesn't like to stick to the norm of one single emotion and is targeted for deletion due to his multi-expressions. He bands up with other malfunctioned emojis in order to escape from the software agents that are hunting them and find the Code to fix Gene. The adventure takes them through various apps like Just Dance, Candy Crush or Instagram. The film is literally a marketing gimmick for phone apps.
The fact that Sir Patrick Stewart appears in the film as the Poop emoji had me worried for a bit, but fortunately his appearance is short and minor.The animations aren't half-bad, but that's about the only good part of the movie. All the jokes fall flat, there was not a single moment where I actually laughed.
Judging by the targeted audience of teens and pre-teens, I expected to have more triumph over toys and merchandise, but it didn't really pick up."The Emoji Movie" is a film that shouldn't have been made and instead should have invested the budget into something else.

We live in a society 💔😭
Also the main character, Gene, is hot.
Its a different movie from I have watched before. As an expert in animated movies I can tell you, you won't regret it.

reviews.review_title: An Icon Of Lost Potential: A Serious Review of The Emoji Movie
reviews.content: In today's world, the phone isn't used quite as the inventors pictured, with actual calling being replaced by texting and snapchat. But one item has been developed to replace the words that are too difficult to write: Emojis. In desperation, Sony has developed a film about these icons in an attempt to break the bank with another hit animated series. Can they succeed, or will this movie be nothing but a bombardment of sad faced emojis? Robbie K here to answer that question for you with another review. LIKES:The Animation: You can say a lot of negative things about the movie, but one plus for this reviewer is the beautiful display Sony's team has designed. Like many movies, the characters move with fluid grace, transitioning through their adventure with little jumpiness. High Five (James Corden) in particular has impressive moves, as having a hand expand beyond simple hand movements can be tricky business. In addition, I enjoyed the visualization of the world within our phone, finding clever design in the development of the internal universes of each app (primarily Instagram's frozen pictures). I'll admit, the characters aren't realistic like Pixar, or even super creative design, but there is cleverness in the world itself. It's Cute: When it comes to cartoons/animated marvels, the pendulum can swing to either side of the age spectrum. Fear not those with little kids, this movie is certainly geared towards the younger side, filled to the brim with color, simplistic jokes, and over the top slapstick that will make many giggle. Sure, there are a few drier jokes that adults will get, but for the most part this movie goes back to basics for family friendliness. One won't have to worry about inappropriate gestures or innuendos in this film. The Morals: Movies are a powerful tool to teach the lessons we humans are too ignorant to learn from mentors, school, and the quickly fading trend of reading. Emoji's movie solid lesson of being yourself and not conforming to the traditional ways is as good rehash of the traditional lesson. Those who stand out from the norm will find great relevance to Gene (T.J. Miller) and Jailbreak's (Anna Faris) quest and most likely grab on to the characters. It's also always good to see a lesson in friendship as well, quoting the movie as "Better to have one good friend, than a bunch of fake fans followers". The strong emphasis on this will hopefully break through the persistent firewalls of your subconscious and get you contacting your buddies. DISLIKES:Story: Despite the morals infused into the story, the overall quality of Gene's tale is very basic at best. The Emoji movie has little sustenance to it, diving more into cramming the jokes in the short run time. After all the world building I had hoped for a little more depth to navigating the apps, facing the dangers of the cyber terror that lurk in our phones. I wanted suspense! I wanted exploration of a selection of apps. I wanted an adventure that had a little more depth behind it. I got very little of that. All the obstacles they faced were fairly easy to circumvent, and often not worth mentioning at how lame they were. Certainly, they did a few things right (Just Dance 4), but for the most part, it was a huge loss of potential at decoding the craziness of our obsession with phones. Humor: Humor can be fun when balanced, but unfortunately Emoji movie lacks that balance, once again swinging the pendulum to the younger audience. Most of the jokes are very simple statements that lack any finesse, or decent delivery to maximize the laughs. Much of the humor is dry, and although has adult components, lacks that clever zing that other films/programs do. James Corden rectifies this a little with High Fives self-absorbed personality, but even his banter gets stale after a while. With all of the comedians in this movie, I really had expected more of this movie, but again missed potential. Boring: If you haven't gleamed it from the first two categories, then this should sum this up, Emoji movie is boring. There is no suspense to the adventure, and let's face it no point, to the challenges at hand. I found myself looking at the clock wondering how much longer I had in the ridiculous presentation of smart phone gimmicks. Cute is always great, but it is better left to YouTube and Kid shows that are in short spans of time. Without the jokes to back it up, nor an impressive voice performance, there is just little to scream entertainment outside of watching a child's smile light up at the colorful presentation. The VERDICT:You've seen the reviews of my colleagues, and they aren't far from the truth Emoji movie was a miss for Sony in terms of quality. The lackluster jokes, lack of challenge, and reserved wit were not the right steps to take in this inconsistent adventure for success. In fact, the best thing of this film is the animated short for Hotel Transylvania that precedes it. Still, if you are looking for a safe, family trip to the movies, you've got the Emoji movie to save your bacon. However, I highly recommend reserving this one for Netflix. My scores are:Animation/Adventure/Comedy: 4.0 Movie Overall: 2.0

Are you sure, 'a picture is worth a thousand words'!? It seems, by this picture that it isn't. From a filmmaking perspective, this movie directed by Anthony Leonis tanked on several levels from unfunny cringe-worthy dialogue and jokes from comedy writers, Mike White & Eric Siegel to extremely rushed jarring animation from Sony Animation Studios to meet the deadline, thus making certain frames of uneven motion. However, I do appreciate, what, Leondis was trying to go for. I kinda dig, unlocking the digital world, inside your smartphone. After all, I'm a huge fan of a similar concept, in which South Park, unlocked, the Facebook app in Season 14th, Episode 4 'You Have 0 Friends'. I also understand, what the director wanted with the protagonist, Gene Meh (Voiced by T.J Miller) being different from the other emojis and trying to find his place, in a world, where everybody expects you to be one thing. It's something, people can relate to. I also comprehend the purpose of using an emoji, when it come to the digital age. They are a good addition to express emotions in the otherwise very emotion-less world of instant messaging and typed up conversations on the computer. Plus, they really do cut down, on the amount of words & sentences, it takes to text somebody. Nevertheless, emojis also come across, as annoying if use incorrectly; which seem to happen right here. Instead, of cutting down, screen-time, the emojis in this film, add more. They are just way, too talkative. A good example is, sidekick, Hi-5 (Voiced by James Corden), whom character seems to drag the plot down with his endless amount of chitchat & tomfoolery, after the 1st act. There were a lot of moments that they could cut, with him. One great example is the trash app escape scene in the middle act. What was the point of seeing that, if we going to see, yet another delete moment near the climax? In truth, it was completely unnecessary & kinda ruin the tension, knowing that delete emojis can come back. Not only that, some of the other emojis subplot are also extremely excessive. Why do, Gene's parents, Mel Meh (Voiced by Steven Wright) & Mary Meh (Voiced by Jennifer Coolidge) have a time-consuming sequence of them, looking for Gene!? Couldn't that, be cut, in order, to focus more on Gene's self-discovery. Also, learning, where Gene got, his special powers, kinda ruins the mystique. It just doesn't help, the plot. Another thing, the movie could had delete, was Jailbreak (Voiced by Anna Faris)'s subplot, about complaining about sexism and gender inequality. This isn't the film for that; seeing how the film showcases multiple examples of female emojis who aren't tied to a gender-specific-role, including Smiler (Voiced by Maya Rudolph) and Gene's mom. Also, whether or not, Jailbreak has legitimate feelings for Gene, shouldn't had been a focus. The idea that Gene turn back to a meh, because of reject love than reprogramming, is a bit shallow and horrible clichés. It makes the whole journey to the cloud, pointless. Things like that, shouldn't had been brought up, if they were going with feminism approach with the character. It's clear, that this film has a desire to say something about the modern day world, but it lack the sophistical story-telling, needed to provide social commentary. There is no greater example of that, than the movie botch-attempt on addressing the negative issues of mobile phone have on contemporary society, through the viewpoint of Gene's phone owner, Alex (Voiced by Jake T. Austin). It's here, where the movie shows the extreme changes on the conversation style from face-to-face to text based conversation, adverse effects on relationships, distractions, and lack of emotional depth. However, it was all wasted potential, as the movie went back on everything, it was originally, trying to say, about being too dependence on your phone with having a emoji tell, all of your complex feelings for you; instead of just using your mouth. It's a totally misguided message that undermine everything, this movie was building up for. Call me dark, but I would rather see, the bitter ending of seeing the phone information get delete & reborn, than this sorry forced happy go lucky ending. The idea that, Alex is able to stop the Factory Reset process mid-way & keep a broken troublesome phone, full of bugs, viruses & bots, even if it is ruining his life, because of one good glitch message seem a bit unrealistic. It's clear, by this movie that, the writers have no idea, how smartphone honestly works. I guess, they also never heard of emoji conveying more than one emotion; which they can do, in real life. Simple put it, the ending was dumb, and it could had been smarter. Another thing about the story, whether intentional or not, the film feels like a very generic grab bag of elements lifted directly from many other successful animated films from the past few years, such as 2014's 'The Lego Movie' 2015's 'Inside Out' & 2012's 'Wreck It Ralph'. Just without any of those film's emotional insight or subtlety. The short animation film 'Puppy' had more emotional depth than this film. Overall: Despite, the great talents and charisma of its voice cast & alright animation from Sony Animation Studios. The movie feels more like a giant advertisement for phone apps, made obvious by the blatant and shameless product placement like "Spotify", "Twitter", "Candy Crush", and "Just Dance Now'. Added, the awful marketing with 2017's TV Show, 'Handmaiden Tales' & you got yourself, a horrible movie, not worth watching. Its inability to deliver emotionally or thematically keeps it from ever feeling like a worthwhile experience. This is one movie worth deleting.

reviews.review_title: World record for worst IMDb rating? *poop emoji* Yup.
reviews.content: We have here the world record for worst IMDb rating of only 1.5. I'm pretty sure it's going to get lower lol. Seriously, why didn't anyone put some effort into this? I really didn't like this movie. I watched it on a whim, with the idea of, 'It can't be that bad'. Sadly, I was wrong. The movie is from start to finish stupid. It relies on the audiance also being stupid, and eventually a non-sense plot point. It is bad, it is the prime example of lazy, soulless cash grab movies that have no greater goal than making a little more than the cost of production and advertising. The Emoji movie is the blandest meal you can ever have. There is nothing outright offensive, or horrible about it, but that is what makes it even worse, it is... nothing.There is no difference between this movie and glaring at a wall with nothing happening for an hour and a half. The Emoji movie dresses up the fact that nothing happens under this feel good story about being yourself, but they don't realize they also have a glaring contradiction to that narrative in the form of one of the main characters. The Character Jailbreak, I'll touch on that under the cut. The overall message of the movie for Gene, the lead emoji voiced by TJ Miller is this, Be yourself no matter how many people it kills. It is a shitty movie with no thought put into it.It is a bad movie, skip it. It has bad morals, bad values, bad humor, and all around is dumb, dumb dumb dumb. On a more technical level the animation is fine, a bit dry and soulless and too rounded with no real distinction giving it this made by committee feel but that is about as nice as I can be.Overall: 2 out of 10, I don't recommend this movie. It sucks and actively teaches harmful morals and values.Spoiler Stuff
So one of the side characters in the movie is a female emoji named Jailbreak, who is an elite hacker and the smartest character in the movie, because of girl power. A girl can have no weaknesses after all in this era of filmmaking. However, that isn't my issue with her, movies are fantasy, characters are allowed to be super humanly gifted, in fact, part of the appeal of movies is seeing people who are good at things, that inspire us to be good at things. My issue with the character of Jailbreak is her 'character arc' if it can be called such a thing.Jailbreak, out of the blue, is revealed to be the missing princess emoji. So she can sing and summon the twitter logo and other such cheesy and stupid things. However, the issue is actually, her arc contradicts the moral the movie is pushing with Gene.Gene has made the choice to be himself pretty much, even if it gets literally everyone in the phone he lives in deleted. You know, be yourself no matter who you kill. Jailbreak however has decided to rebel completely against the identity she was assigned, Princess, until it was convenient to be a princess, then she was one. It is kind of a BS cop out just to give her new powers. She does go back to being the cool hacker princess in the end, but for the time she is doing princess stuff, it is on surface level the rejection of the shitty moral the rest of the movie pushes.Now the idea of the message, be yourself is fine, kids should hear messages close to that, however... In the context of this movie, Be yourself means killing everyone you have ever known. Being yourself means ruining the lives of everyone around you. I'm not advocating for conformity necessarily, but the movie having a nice wrap up where everything works out including the reversal of what we are told is permanent deletion at the Phone store, is stupid. The message of Be Yourself always needs the caveat of, there are consequences, there are downsides to non-conformity, and you have to make the message that, it is a struggle to find yourself but is also about compromising with the status quo, the society.After all, aren't most murders just being themselves?
At one point in the movie they were facing the firewall. It was a pit bull song where it says "Im a fireball" when it clearly should've been 'Im a firewall'.Overall the movie was 'meh'.

Boy what a piece of 💩! There is absolutely no reason for this movie to exist - none. To make a movie about Legos or Transformers or My Little Pony is one thing, but making an entire movie about the text app on your phone is the equivalent of making a movie called The Secret Life of Smoke Signals. The fact that the movie centers on the "😕" emoji is, in a way, kind of ironic. "😕," is quite literally the best thing you can say about this movie. The worst you can say, is it made this reviewer want to 🤢.The (ugh) Emoji Movie follows a few days in the life of Gene Meh (Miller), an Emoji who for some reason doesn't have the ability to do a "Meh" on cue. As a result of a first day screw up, Gene becomes a social pariah and risks deletion unless he can find a code that will change his programming for the better...I guess. Along for the ride is former user favorite High-Five (Corden), and the mysterious Hacker named Jailbreak (Farris) who isn't who she says she is but her big, third act reveal means little, and does little other than prop up a cynical Twitter ad.To the surprise of absolutely no one, The Emoji Movie is chalked full of low-hanging fruit when it comes to jokes and basic story elements. But what is surprising is there's so little of anything actually going on. For real though! In between page long exposition dumps, plot contrivance dumps and forced, cringe-worthy youth-oriented vocab dumps, the jokes seem to be spewing at 30% capacity and the plot seems barely alive. It's essentially a movie of surface level dynamics and empty space.What little we have to grab onto in this godforsaken movie is Meh's ambiguously set up heroes journey. A journey that literally takes him, his friends and his family through Facebook, Youtube, Spotify and Dropbox because, you know, what's a movie like this without cat videos, malware updates, bad pop music and "thumbs up" stickers. There's also a trek through Candy Crush which not only feels uninspired but does the unthinkable in taking a beat to actually explain the game lest someone in the audience still holds onto their rotary. It all reaches peak stupidity when Meh manages to travel to "the cloud" thanks largely to his ability to make faces and remember the name of the girl the phone's user is obsessed with.The final act makes no sense but trust me, by the point Meh makes his return to Textopolis (no joke, the Emojis live in Textopolis), the movie is so far gone, you'll just be glad it's a few minutes from wrapping up. When it finally does wrap up the only question you'll probably be asking yourself is, "am I angry that I saw this movie, or am I just angry that it wasted my time?" With a threadbare story and failing significantly to reach already low expectations, The Emoji Movie is arguably the worst movie of the summer. And this is the same summer that brought us the The Mummy (2017) and that's say something! Everything it does has been done before and better, and what it manages to do differently is so cynically implemented and poorly thought out. This isn't a movie, it's a tweet that's grown sentient.

reviews.review_title: One of the most soulless "movies" I have ever had the displeasure of watching
reviews.content:
Pros:
-The movie, as bad as it is, actually looks pretty great. Shoutout to the animation team for at least trying to make this movie have any redeeming qualities.
-There is like, two or three good ideasCons:
-Even without all of the other cons, this movie would've still been a predictable, unoriginal, cliched, boring, and forgettable piece of (poop emoji)
-The writing is INFURIATINGLY awful. I had to pause the movie so many times to let the stupidity sink in.
-The "jokes", if you can call them that, are all either bad visual gags or awful "puns" that don't even make sense half of the time. There were a few times when I was a little close to laughing, and two times when I genuinely laughed, but the rest of it is garbage.
-This movie has some of the worst product placement I have ever seen. They weren't trying to be even a little subtle, it just felt like I was watching a big ad for a bunch of apps, with an awful movie in between the ads.
-The characters are bad. Gene is just an uninteresting "meh" protagonist. High-five is very annoying, and I don't buy his friendship with Gene at all. He just seemed to tag along on the adventure for his own personal gain that I didn't care about. Jailbreak is a somewhat boring character who randomly spouts out feminist remarks from time to time, and does some EXTREMELY out of character things near the end of the movie. Again, I don't buy her relationship with Gene, but at least it isn't the most forced in relationship I've ever seen.
-This movie doesn't seem to have rules. Here are some examples (minor spoilers):
"He is going to go to the phone store to delete us tomorrow!" After what seems like a few minutes in the movie's time: "We only have 4 hours before the phone is deleted!"
"We have to travel to the other side of the phone to get to the trash to save High Five from being deleted!" Later: "Here, I can pull up this email you found and left in the trash on my screen."
Not to mention, a large amount of things that happen in the movie are just not how phones work at all. Also, many plot holes and things that didn't make sense were created just to throw in more ads.
-There were some subplots, but I din't care at all about them. At least they were breaks from the infuriating main plot
-The voice acting is sub-standardI know there are worse movies out there, but this is one of the worst movies I have ever seen. Don't watch this ad that is calling itself a movie. It is not so bad it's good, it's just infuriating, and it will be forgotten within a year or two.

Grade: DRating: PG, 86 minutesIn a Nutshell: Meh. Rumor has it that this film was Sony's last effort to make a good movie before going bankrupt. I doubt that's true, but I have a feeling they're not going to be posting any happy emojis when they see how audiences are reacting to this disappointing movie.Unfortunately, It appears to be a blatant money grab, as well as a copycat of Pixar's successful movie Inside Out (Theatrical). Based on the idea that high schooler's lives revolve around cell phones, the animated emojis live in a colorful, nonsensical world called Textropolis. In fact, the narrator (Meh) exclaims cell phones as the "most important invention in the history of communication." Ummm...no. I love using emojis too, but I love language even more...and real human interaction.Uplifting theme: Individuality, express yourself "Being #1 doesn't matter if there aren't any other numbers." – Meh, Jail Break "I'd rather have a real friend." – Meh, hand It's OK to have a lot of different emotions. Friendship, loyaltyThings I liked: The talented voice cast includes T.J. Miller, James Corden, Anna Faris, Maya Rudolph, Steven Wright, Jennifer Coolidge, Christina Aguilera, and Sofia Vergara. Can you believe Patrick Stewart plays "Poop"?! Good music. The parents of "Meh" talk in monotone, which is pretty funny, especially when you recognize comedian Steven Wright's voice who is absolutely perfect for his role. The YouTube video of the kitten getting tickled got more reaction out of the audience than anything else in the entire movie. Tons of poop jokes. Who doesn't love the poop emoji? Some movie critics are using it to describe this movie. The poop emojis are in a lot of scenes and easy to write gags for. I thought it was cute when the young poop followed his dad out of the bathroom with toilet paper stuck on his foot. There's a quick look at WeChat, which Meh describes as "a whole other world." That's for sure. I've been to China twice this year and have been completely amazed with WeChat. You can invite a friend out to dinner, make a reservation at a restaurant, call a taxi service to take you there, pay for dinner, and all without ever leaving the app. You can even pay for vending machines, go shopping, shake your cell phone to win prizes, and soooooo much more, all on WeChat. It's like all of America's apps built into one. When you see The Emoji Movie in the movie theater, you'll also get to see the animated short called "Puppy", based on the characters from Hotel Transylvania.Things I didn't like: Really dumb script and plot. It's just not funny. When I arrived in the theater, kids were bouncing out of their seats with excitement. Once the movie started, they became almost comatose. Predictable, obligatory dance number at the end of the movie that fell flat.Funny lines: "My mom just joined Facebook. Can you believe she wanted to friend me?" – school girl "We're number two! We're number two!" – poop emojis "What could a teenage boy possibly want to hide from his parents?" - Meh (T.J. Miller)Dumb lines: "We have business to attend to." – monkey emojis "What kind?" – Meh "Monkey business!" – monkey emojis "Words aren't cool." – boy's friend' "That's what matters in life: popularity." – High 5 (James Corden) Tips for parents: Your kids deserve a better movie. Talk of piracy, skins, and a ton of social media programs.MOVIE REVIEW MOM@trinaboice

I thought this movie could be atleast a little bit creative but it isn't in the sligthest. I found my self having to use my phone during the whole movie cause I was so bored. Very lousy job of Sony animation studios.

reviews.review_title: What is the point of this movie?
reviews.content: Hollywood is running out of ideas. How would a movie about emojis be good? The whole idea just seemed terrible and uncreative. And they probably couldn't think of any good story to come out of EMOJIS so they decided to take Wreck it Ralph and Inside Out, mix them up in a blender, and came out with The Emoji Movie.This movie opens up with 13-year-olds walking around looking at their phone all the time because hey, that's what 13 year olds are obsessing over these days. But this movie just paints every single 13 year old kid as a phone-obsessed geek but coming from a sheltered person, I know that's not true. I'm sure nobody has their whole entire life revolve around their phone.The characters are one-dimensional and typical. You got hi-five, the happy, hyper emoji, Jailbreak, the emo emoji, Alex, the love interest who's shy and giddy around his girlfriend, ew Poopdaddy emoji, and Gene, the expressive emoji who just wants to be like the other emojis and make a meh expression. And of course, you got two emojis falling in love. A lot of the characters in this movie are douchebaagsA lot of the things in this movie did not make sense and are stupid that I could nit-pick but there is too many to list. I did crack a smile or chuckle at like a few parts but a lot of the jokes are either corny or ridiculous.The only good thing I would say about this movie is the animation is pretty decent. The characters look cute and charming and the voice acting was pretty good except Maya Rudolph always sounded like she had her mouth hanging open.Who are the people that made this movie? It's like a very young child wrote this. I imagine kids under 11 would probably like this but I don't think older kids will.Verdict: Just a terrible cash-grab that's loud and full of pop culture. This movie is essentially unoriginal.

reviews.review_title: The makers of this film must think we are idiots. This is an insult to humans' intelligence.
reviews.content: The idea of this was great, but by making it the way they did, I will never look at an emoji the same way.In this film, we are treated as if we are brainless drones. Did the makers assume we would not notice that The Emoji Movie is one giant advertisement? Because that is all this movie is. Two tutorials on how to play games, and many demonstrations of how great phone's apps are. I wasted an hour and thirty-one minutes on my life watching this, when I would much rather have been sitting bored at home.The plot was messy and stupid, containing one pathetic joke after the next. The trailer was more entertaining. I will not be surprised if next year, a fidget spinner movie is released.This is also offensive to high-school aged students, as the beginning literally states that as a high-school student, Alex's entire life revolves around his phone. Another thing about that is that all they do 24/7 is text, and all they seem to use are emojis. Are the script-writers saying that all a high-school student does throughout the course of their day is press little icons on his phone to send to others?Why did people fight over creating this monstrosity? People in the year 3017 are going to look back on July 18, 2017 as the year humanity was at its lowest pitfall. Historians will marvel at how a movie that sucked so much managed to sell even one ticket after opening night.I want my life back.

I knew this movie is going to be that bad.I don't think it's necessary to make movies like this.Comparing The Emoji Movie with Foodfight, you can tell that both of the stories had made NO sense whatsoever.Don't get me wrong, I enjoy other animated movies made by Sony like Open Season and Monster House, but my question to Sony is...WHY???

I don't know what kind of airhead would think this is a good film idea, but it actually wasn't the nightmare I expected it to be. That's all I'll say for now, as I can hear crowds of people getting tomatoes to throw at me.

reviews.review_title: I didn't like the film that much, but...product placement? Really?
reviews.content: The Emoji Movie sucks. There's no doubt about it. The reason I hated this film was because of it's poorly written script and tired, unfunny jokes (except when High Five tried to make a fist, that was funny). But the main reason this film is hated (according to WatchMojo, anyway) is product placement. I mean, what the hell?! I guess Toy Story sucks then, because there's a Slinky Dog and a Mr. Potato Head, and a few mentions of Mattel and Nintendo. Or because of the DeLorean, Back to the Future is the worst movie in existence, along with Spider-Man: Into the Spiderverse, cause that has Nikes in it. Except none of those films suck at all. Product placement does not justify a movie's quality. So hate The Emoji Movie all you want, just don't pick dumb reasons.
It was what it is a cute movie about emojis in a phone...stop tring to make it gone with the wind

reviews.review_title: Can't see why it got such low reviews, nice and average children movie
reviews.content: first time writing a review because i can't see why it's so hated. When me and my bf saw it has 1.9 stars, we immediately decided to go watch it the same day. by the time we arrived the cinema, the rating has dropped to 1.4 stars. we were sure it's gonna be ridiculously bad and we are gonna spend a good time laughing about it. well, we paid to watch the movie only to find out it's a decent, even kinda nice children's movie. yeah, not one of the best I saw but defiantly not the worst as well. if i could i would give it around 6.5, I think. as an adult, the movie wasn't very interesting. but there were some stuff i found kinda neat, like (((spoiler)) the smiley girl who's always happy but turns crazy murderous in the middle while keeping a happy image. yeah, not a genius concept but defiantly brought a little more depth. there were many cringe-worthy moments in the film, but the same as every other children film. to conclude, i don't think the movie is amazingly good, but it's defiantly not very bad either. i think it is nice for small children.

This film is more than a film. It's art. Out of the many outstanding qualities the themes are the most impressive. It serves as a reflection on our own society, the breaking of norms and the oppressive Orwellian government pushing what's different down. True authenticity is a rarity in our culture, with the transcendent message of the film and the innovative concept and animation. The way this film was done has never been done before. Ever. There is literally nothing like it. Focusing instead on making a masterpiece rather than making money, instead of being an half assed ad like Anomalisa. The Emoji restores my faith in film and in turn restores my faith in humanity. Definitely deserves it's own cinematic universe. 10 out of 10.

I was forced to watch it with my siblings and I hated every minute of it, I came out of the cinema just to realize that I wasted 1hr 30 minutes of my life watching this garbage.It is one of the most unoriginal movies I have ever seen in my entire life, its setting and theme are literally derived from films like Wreck-It Ralph, Inside Out and The Lego Movie.I mean Jailbreak, is literally a copy-paste of Lucy from the lego movie, and Gene is derived from Ralph in Wreck-It Ralph and Emmet from the Lego Movie, and HI-5 who is meant to be funny sidekick is more obnoxious than funny, I mean come on, his jokes are literally the most unfunniest anyone would ever think of, even children would not laugh at.Even the animation is the laziest I have seen especially considering that this was released in 2017, I mean Pixar films of the 1990s (Toy Story, A Bug's Life & Toy Story 2) were better animated than this piece of trash.One last thing, I still do not understand how can a loving God give people such a horrendous idea for a film and the ability to even make and release it.Please, for the love of all that is holy, DO NOT WATCH THIS FILM, I literally lost 10% of my braincells this watching and wasted 1hr 30min of my life and even questioned the existence of God after realising that he would let a film this bad go into theaters.
This movie sucks but there are some redeeming qualities like nice animation, only 1 good joke,decent soundtrack and good songs, and decent voice acting
Trash. That's what this movie is. Don't even bother watching. Save yourself.

I feel like this movie hits the hearts of millions of middle class individuals around the world. The plain, cliché story line is not only an expertly crafted piece of literature in the form of a film, but because it is completely substance-less and was only created to be relatable to the audience. You can genuinely feel the character's emotions inside of you as if you were there. The seemingly confusing concept of three simultaneous stories that have little correlation to each other only creates a huge wave of creativity within the writer's room. This is easily visible by the many heart-warming and saddening scenes within "The Emoji Movie". A scene brimming with emotions was presented to us with the subtle yet moving "Candy Crush" mobile application. The story's prime protagonist, Gene, is stuck inside the game. However, because his friend, Hi-5, resembles the architecture of a human hand, he is able to bamboozle the game in order to free his chum, Gene. This supposedly insignificant scene portrays a tale of true friendship and belief. Hi-5 was willing to accept his characteristics, and felt great to be himself.

THIS MOVIE IS BAD.

I had some concerns that all the hate for this movie was founded, but I have found that a lot of either box-office bombs or hated movies or both are actually better than people make out (with the exception of The Adventures of Scooter the Penguin), so I decided that I would give it a go.
Now, this is by far the most unoriginal movie ever - it's general plot, themes, and stuff are all stuff that we've seen time and time again.
It has some of the cheesiest lines in history (with Aquaman coming in a close second).
It is also extremely predictable.
But it has a talented cast who's voices are just perfect for their roles, great animation, and you know what? It doesn't hurt to hear the message that this movie showcases once again as it is actually relevant.
And while it is predictable it also is entertaining enough to keep you interested. Though, if you don't like the plot, give it a shot for the music. The music in it is fantastic, even if you don't like the plot.
It's meant to be a funny, feel-good, charming movie greatly succeeds in that regard.
Give it a shot, though I can't guarantee whether or not you'd like it.

reviews.review_title: This one is well worth a chance
reviews.content:
Come on people, why is everybody so harsh? This may not be Kung-Fu Panda or The Incredibles, but it sure isn't a three star animated movie. :)
Yes the animation is "emoji" (average) style but then again it kind of adds to the feeling of the movie. 
Pros - short and fast paced (not a minute dragged), quite original concept of the "phone world", has the expected friends&family values you expect from a teenage oriented movie, AND you'll have a constant smile on your face.
Cons - may be a bit predictable (yet not boring), some parts sound like a commercial indeed and aimed at teenagers (pro or con, depending on your age).
Overall, an amusing movie well worth your time. Great for some afternoon relaxing time.

reviews.review_title: Stereotypical, Confusing, and Just Plain Awful....
reviews.content: No, I am not writing this review just because of what people have said, I'm writing on how I think of this movie in MY OPINION!!! As a 12th grader, I think this is really offensive to other High-Schoolers, people basically think that all High school kids do is mindlessly text, not pay attention in class and play with our phones, and act like slaves to technology to the point where we act brainless and fail everything in life...thus why adults are labeling us as parasitic, childish, dependent millennials True, we may text and go on social media, but we are not hooked to the point of completely ignoring school as a whole....We do not live lives completely revolved around our phone...That's just an offensive stereotype...﻿ The movie itself is also VERY confusing, the Animation is passable, Voice are Fine, but I could not understand any of the movie, I get the whole "Express Yourself how you want to" message, but Emojis are NOT an ideal subject to use this message with since all emojis have a single task and having 1 emoji have a multiple emotions and wants to change and express himself...it just doesn't comprehend...Heck, It would be better if they used Play-Doh and made a Play-Doh Movie, at least it would MAKE SENSE FOR THE EXPRESS YOURSELF MESSAGE!!! In short, this movie is a bad influence for kids, offensive to high-schoolers, and confusing to the point of not even bothering to see anymore of it I was lucky to actually make it through the film without getting angry at the blatant product placements and teen stereotypes...Overall, I cannot forgive this movie, and it deserves the 0% on Rotten Tomatoes...Admit it Sony, you've flopped again!!

reviews.review_title: A Very Atrocious Movie. By Far One Of The Worst of Year
reviews.content: "The Emoji Movie" is Hollywood's next attempt to make anything a "thing." The Emoji movie is about a meh emoji who may have a malfunction and some other stuff happens along the way. I don't really know. And I don't really care.The thing with animated movies is that you have to make them appealing to both kids and adults. This was neither. Adults will be bored with it, but at least kids will have fun right? Wrong. When the kid next to me is asleep a half hour into the movie and the girl in front of me leans over to her mother and asks "Mom is the movie over yet," that is a problem within itself. There are so many bad attempts at humor in this film. The "poop emoji" is there for the poop jokes and there are other characters that have bad puns. Apparently this is what quailifies as humor now. It wasn't funny. I didn't laugh once throughout the entirety of the runtime. And the second half of this film is just a music video. Song after song plays, you see emojis dancing, and the movie stops taking itself seriously. Not like it ever did in the first place anyways. I just never thought a movie would be dumb enough to make it self a music video again after Suicide Squad did that.This movie loses your interest almost immediately. Movies like this have to be fun, entertaining, and interesting. There were so many scenes in this film where I was drifting off thinking about my next day's activities.This is worse than Transformers 5. Sadly almost as bad as Fifty Shades Darker.I am going to give "The Emoji Movie" a fat F, which is equivalent to the Poop emoji.Check out my review here on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FXA2cj6_bnw&t=1s

Most people would be surprised to learn how much more there is to the emoji phenomenon than little digital icons which we use to express emotion or represent activities or locations in our text messages. For instance, did you know that the word emoji has nothing to do with the words emotion or emoticon? Emoji is a combination of the Japanese words for "picture" and "character". Emojis started appearing on Japanese cell phones in the late 1990s. When they began showing up in the U.S. on the Apple iPhone in 2011, soon followed by other smart phones, emojis truly became a global phenomenon. So much so that there's even an annual World Emoji Day – and an international organization which regulates emojis!July 17th is World Emoji Day because that's the date the calendar emoji shows, but every day is emoji day for the non-profit Unicode Consortium. According to a July 16, 2017 "USA Today" article, "The Unicode Emoji Subcommittee determines which characters will become part of the official emoji lexicon, creating a uniform code that can be used across platforms." The article also says that the consortium, which has been around since 1988, is striving to be more inclusive and representative when it comes to race, gender and sexual orientation, pointing out that, at press time, there were 2,666 approved emojis.Of course, the business and regulatory aspects of emojis don't matter to the people who send the 6 billion emoji-enhanced text messages worldwide every single day. They're just looking for a more complete way to express themselves digitally, to add a little emotional context to their messages. More than just being "cute", emojis help us communicate more effectively in our increasingly digital world. And with emojis increasingly prevalent in our daily text messages and Emails, is it any wonder that they would make their way onto movie screens too? And we get just that with the animated adventure comedy "The Emoji Movie" (PG, 1:26) bringing to "life" those little yellow faces and other digitized objects in the summer of 2017, less than two weeks after the 4th (yes, 4th) annual World Emoji Day.Alex (voiced by Jake T. Austin from the Disney Channel's "Wizards of Waverly Place") is a typical teenager. He doesn't like school, but he does like a girl in his school, a pretty young lady named Addie (Tati Gabrielle). Of course, he tries to communicate with her through his smart phone, but he finds it difficult – because he's shy, but also because his phone seems to have a mind of its own these days. Little does Alex know, but inside his phone is a virtual city called Textopolis, which is where emojis live and work. The job of all the emojis is to stand by for Alex to call upon them in a text message and, when chosen, to present their best individual image as he or she is scanned for a digital text transmission.Gene (T.J. Miller) is excited and nervous because this is his first day on the job as an emoji – the "meh" emoji. His parents, Mr. & Mrs. Meh (Steven Wright and Jennifer Coolidge), aren't sure he's ready, but he assures them that he is and he takes his position in his cube, waiting to be chosen to appear in a text message. When Alex chooses the meh emoji for a text to Addie, Gene freaks out during his scan, causing Alex to embarrass himself by sending Addie a very odd-looking emoji that she doesn't understand. Gene's mistake causes Smiler (Maya Rudolph), the head emoji, to label Gene a "malfunction" and order that he be deleted. Gene makes a run for it and Smiler sends menacing black bots after him.Gene's "problem" is that he feels and expresses more emotions than meh. Now, besides being frustrated that he can't just be the meh that he was born to be, he has endangered the entire emoji community. If Alex thinks there's something wrong with his phone, he may just have it wiped clean. Hoping to get "fixed", Gene teams up with the hand emoji Hi-5 (James Corden), who is upset that he's no longer in the Favorites Lounge, and the two of them go in search of a hacker named Jailbreak (Anna Faris). Jailbreak is uninterested in helping them until she sees that Gene can show multiple emotions. She decides to help them get to a magical place called The Cloud where all of them may find the solutions to their problems. As the three emojis work their way through Alex's phone (while trying to steer clear of the bots), they cause various apps to malfunction, making even more problems for Alex."The Emoji Movie" is derivative and not very enjoyable. The story, directed and co-written by Tony Leondis ("Lilo & Stitch: Stitch Has a Glitch") is a combination of "Inside Out", "Toy Story", "Divergent" and "The Wizard of Oz", but not nearly as good as any of them. The script finds many opportunities for humor in actual cell phone usage and the emojis that "live" in them, but the movie just isn't all that funny. There are positive lessons about the bonds of friendship and being the best version of yourself regardless of what others think, but those ideas have been portrayed more effectively by countless other movies before this one. "The Emoji Movie" is clever enough, but entertaining? Not enough. "C"

reviews.review_title: I'm Sorry To Rate This A 10 Haters
reviews.content: I Actually Like This Movie, This Movie Is Peaceful But Sometimes CringyWhy Do People Really Hate This Movie, What Does It Do To You

Gene is a "Meh" emoji. The problem is that he can't keep his feelings hidden, which means that he is pretty useless at conveying "Meh", which causes his his user Alex problems when trying to impress Addie. Gene, due to be deleted, escapes in the company of Hi-5 and Jailbreak, to try to get Gene reprogrammed.This CGI feature has come in for some fairly savage criticism, not all of which is fair. There is some excellent voice casting (headed by TJ Miller, who specialises in playing Protagonist's Annoying Idiot Friend: he is quite good here), some pleasing visual imagination, some smart riffing on mobile phone apps, textspeak. Youth culture and the like (Hi-5 has fallen out of favour following the rise of Fist Bump, for instance), and a little bit of heart.But that plays against the fact that the film scoffs at youngsters' dependence on mobile phones, then unironically bases itself rather triumphally on that very point. And while the film gives every appearance of aiming itself at children, a lot of the content is at a level where it will be understood and appreciated by teenagers/young adults, who will otherwise feel that the film falls well below the sort of film they shouud be enjoying - "This is too young and too childish for me."Mind you, you have to love a film where Sir Patrick Stewart plays Poop, don't you?

💩Just by writing this review, I probably spent more time on The Emoji Movie than anyone involved with the script. I'm concerned that by calling this a garbage fire, I'll be doing an injustice to garbage fires. This movie sounded like an inane idea when announced, looked terrible in the trailers, nonetheless surprised me by being worse than I expected. If you can envision a place where creativity goes to die this is it. It represents all the worst elements of Sony as a studio and of Hollywood in general.Remember "Inside Out" from a couple of years ago? Did you ever imagine what it would be like if that movie replaced all it's imagination with product placement? That's "The Emoji Movie" in a nutshell: "Inside Out" sans soul.Our main character, Gene (T.J. Miller),is the son of two "meh" emojis (Steven Wright and Jennifer Coolidge) and he too is meant to be a "meh". Sadly,if this movie were "meh" it would be a vast improvement. He's not a very good "meh" and expresses pretty much every emotion except "meh". Because of this, the smiley in charge decides he should be deleted. To escape, he runs off into other phone apps. Remember all the interesting locations the character went through in "Inside Out", well here each of those locations is nothing more than a product placement. Gene and Hi-5 (James Corden), who gets caught up in the "adventure", go to Let's Dance, Candy Crush, Spotify, YouTube, all in an attempt to get to the cloud aka Dropbox. These side quests exist solely to sell products. Sony outpaces other studios in its use of product placement and cross promotion. Thus, "The Emoji Movie" serves as a vehicle for Sony Products and nothing more. Honestly, with all the advertisers featured in this movie it probably paid for itself before one film cell existed.I would say the story is bland and predictable, but in truth it's borderline nonexistent. I wouldn't say it's predictable because that would require an interest in the story's future events when I had none. Literally, I could find nothing to praiseworthy about this movie. Even Patrick Stewart as the Poop emoji never had a chance. What was supposed to pass as humor fell flat. Even when journeying to the separate app, the film's lack of creativity overwhelms everything else. To date, "The Emoji Movie" is the frontrunner for worst movie of the year.
DO NOT WATCH THIS MOVIE. I DID, AND I WILL NEVER GET THOSE 90 MINUTES BACK.

reviews.review_title: I of course wasn't entertained by it, but of course the movie wasn't made for me.
reviews.content: 'THE EMOJI MOVIE': Two and a Half Stars (Out of Five) A computer animated kids movie about a world of living emoji symbols, where a 'meh symbol' malfunctions and is hunted down to be deleted. The film stars the voices of T.J. Miller, James Corden, Anna Faris, Maya Rudolph, Steven Wright and Jennifer Coolidge. It was directed by Tony Leondis, and it was written by Leondis, Eric Siegel and Mike White. The movie has received almost unanimously negative reviews from critics and film fans alike (on IMDb at least), but it did do well at the Box Office still (kids seem to like it). I found it to be pretty pointless, and not really humorous at all, but it's not as bad as the reviews make it out to be either.The story is set in Textopolis; a digital city of emojis that all live inside the phone of a teenager named Alex (Jake T. Austin). Gene (Miller) is a meh symbol, who has the special ability to make many different expressions. On his first day of work, Gene panics and makes the wrong expression. This causes Alex to lose faith in his phone, and it puts all of Textopolis in danger. The leader of the text center, a smiley named Smiler (Rudolph), decides that Gene is a malfunction and she orders him to be deleted. Gene flees, with the help of a once popular emoji named Hi-5 (Corden), who's now lost his fame, and a hacker named Jailbreak (Faris). Smiler sends bots after them to delete Gene.The movie seems like a decent enough kids' flick; it's colorful, adventuresome and mildly amusing (the voice cast does decent enough work too). I of course wasn't entertained by it, but of course the movie wasn't made for me obviously. Kids seem to like it, so it's hard to claim that it's a horrible film. There's not much of anything in there for adults though, and it definitely doesn't have anything of substantial value to teach children. So I'd say it's an OK kids flick at best, that's definitely nothing special (that's for sure).

My name is Yoshikage Kira. I'm 33 years old. My house is in the northeast section of Morioh, where all the villas are, and I am not married. I work as an employee for the Kame Yu department stores, and I get home every day by 8 PM at the latest. I don't smoke, but I occasionally drink. I'm in bed by 11 PM, and make sure I get eight hours of sleep, no matter what. After having a glass of warm milk and doing about twenty minutes of stretches before going to bed, I usually have no problems sleeping until morning. Just like a baby, I wake up without any fatigue or stress in the morning.I was told there were no issues at my last check-up. I'm trying to explain that I'm a person who wishes to live a very quiet life. I take care not to trouble myself with any enemies, like winning and losing, that would cause me to lose sleep at night. That is how I deal with society, and I know that is what brings me happiness. Although, if I were to fight I wouldn't lose to anyone.

0.5/4...And yes I saw it...well, kind of. Half of it at least. This could very well be the worst movie of 2017. It is a movie that only exists due to being in a state of obvious parody. It possesses no merit of its own, it's highly chichéd, and it lacks any kind of originality.The flaws of this movie are so incredibly abundant, that it would take forever to jot them all down. Among the first that come to mind: the bad apple is obvious from the start. It feels political (just look at the emojis confirmed to their communist-like society). There is no emotional connection to any character whatsoever...only whimsical spikes of interest here and there. The script is bland and at times cringy. There is no emotional connection BETWEEN the characters (this is a problem because emojis represent...ah-hem...emotions) and to top it off, it feels second-hand in a very sour way.This movie is a BOMB as far as quality, but I think a 0.5/4 will suffice due to the fun I had laughing at it. It really makes you wonder how stinkers like this makes it past the drawing board.

reviews.review_title: Nice action paced animated movie, that relates to the audience.
reviews.content: I went with my 5 year old daughter and we both liked it. It's not excellent but it's an action paced animated movie that feels good.The plot is at least original. Sure it has lots of product placement but it couldn't be otherwise. Actually the movie is all about product placement. But that's OK, that's actually how it relates to the audience that know each app on our smartphone, and you use them everyday. And that's actually what makes it interesting and compelling. How could a movie about your phone be with fake names and fake apps, it wouldn't make sense.However, the action felt like they were just passing each level, from one app to the other until the final destination. And it's not that funny, but it has some nice funny lines that make you smile (but not laugh). My kid laughed a bit with the easy jokes. Positive points for the animation, liked the Instagram bit especially for the really nice 3D feel.Despicable Me 3 is funnier. Cars 3 is more adventurous. But Emoji relates more to the audience and to the real life.

It's just bad, horrible, terrible, please, avert your eyes from this movie
