reviews.review_title: Excellent Movie ,Unbelievable Why It Is Underrated And Hated!.
reviews.content: Me and my son Muhammad were shocked how this great and funny 3D movie whose budget is 50 million dollars is so underrated and hated. The film centers on Gene, a multi-expressional emoji who lives in a teenager's phone, and who sets out on a journey to become a normal meh emoji like his parents.My son Muhammad and I laughed and saw this movie too entertaining for kids and adults and the thing that convinces us to see despite the unstoppable attack on it is that it has already reached number 1 in the US Box Office and that many open-minded people did not believe the malicious hatred against a quality movie like this.

While the idea of an emoji movie is pretty silly, the introduction with the introduction of the characters is still interesting. Associating a lot of images with something that is nothing more than a series of jokes requires a certain intelligence and ingenuity. A emoji with greater capacity than the rest must face the challenge of discovering himself while joining other emojis that have certain interests. Finally, an evil corporation that directs the destiny of emojis is challenged to put control of the situation lest something finally get out of control. There are references to multiple applications and programs which would charm someone born in this century. There are a couple of great moments (dancing is one of them) and the movie, whether the perfectionists like it or not, isn't that bad.

reviews.review_title: As a thematic where expressions matter the film failed to express!
reviews.content: I agree that this film was not good. Not because of bad writing, animation, voice rendered, but the timing of the film coming out mattered. If this same film was released before 'Wreck it Ralf', 'The Lego Movie', 'Pixels', 'Inside Out', then people might have liked it. But now, it is like Sony desperately wanted their version of toys and/or games related film, so they made it. That's how it looks like. Despite all the criticism, the film minted good sum. So it is not a box office flop, only devalued honestly by those who saw it.Those titles I mentioned and this story has the same storyline. Basically, that's very common platform where 80 per cent of the films borrow from. The scenes looked very ordinary, like there's nothing much to explore. The jokes were weaker, the characters were uninteresting in most of the parts. I would say they did not utilise them rightly. The good thing is, it is a watchable film, but the majority won't like it. Usually Sony animations were met with underwhelmingly, and seeing the response it had got, surely there will be no sequel, at least for now.3/10
Feels like it tries hard to convey an interesting story, but it ends up being dull and irritating.

This movie is garbage! Don't watch it. I took my little sibling to see this (I was forced to) and Im very glad with what I saw: a horrible movie. I wanted this movie to fail simply because of how dumb the idea is, and how cringe worthy it is. Right now, it feels like Christmas for me! The movie is so bland and generic, and cheesy, and illogical, seriously they bombed. See Sony, this is karma for screwing over Spider-Man and all relating characters for the past few years. Next time, stick with a Popeye movie.Now, this review Is just my rant about how much I wanted it to fail. But if I were to put a REAL review in, it'd be this: This is one of the most cliché movies of all time. Its like Sony looked at things like Wreck it Ralph and Finding Dory, and just straight up copied it. But made it worse. The characters are bland, the story is bland, and all the comedy fails. STAY AWAY FROM THIS MESS.And Patrick Stewart, what are you doing here in this mess? You're better than this, man. Cmon. Poop? Really?

Alex is a boy trying to connect with classmate Addie through his phone's messaging app Textopolis. Inside the phone, each app is a world upon itself. In Textopolis, Gene is an emoji eager to follow his parents' footsteps as another Meh. He fails in his first attempt and in the ensuing chaos, emoji leader Smiler sets bots to erase Gene. Hi-5 joins him in escaping into the world of the phone. Hi-5 leads them into a pirate app to find hacker Jailbreak to fix Gene.The start is good. I like the old emoticons walking into the retirement home. Despite the really stupid premise, I'm still willing to give this a chance hoping for some old Tron magic. The start is simply a fake out as the movie deteriorates into nothing. I couldn't stand it even with the very short 80 minutes worth of viewing. The poop jokes are fully expected but still insufferable. Why would Alex send the Meh emoji in the first place? It's all bright colors and meaningless stupidity. It may still be enjoyable for really young kids with their first phones. They may have fun with this idiocy.

When I saw how much hate 'The Emoji Movie' was getting, I decided I had to see it for myself to see if it was justified. An animated kid's film with a sizeable budget couldn't possibly be that bad, right? Wrong. It is every bit as bad as the reviews suggest.This is by far and away the worst animated movie I have ever seen. It has literally nothing going for it, with everything from the plot to the script and characters being nothing short of dreadful. As if the idea itself isn't bad enough, they then have the audacity to stuff it full of product placement. It angers me to think that people actually went to the cinema to see what is effectively a 90 minute long advert.'The Emoji Movie' is just another example of a pitiful Hollywood cash grab, jumping on a social trend to make a quick buck. It is insulting even to the young children it is supposed to please. The worst film of the year by far!

reviews.review_title: I expected it to be much worse
reviews.content: After hearing about how much this movie sucks, and seeing the abysmal 1,6 rating it has, I decided to watch this movie just to laugh at how bad it is. If I had hoped it was a great movie, I would have been disappointed, but because I went in with the lowest expectations, I was actually positively surprised.The Emoji Movie is an average children's animated movie with high-quality animation, cute but kind of bland characters, and a very archetypal plot with a couple of plot holes. The jokes made me smile and occasionally laugh a little. It's nowhere near as offensive as it should be to deserve all the negative reviews. It's been called just a big advertisement, but I believe apps are a part of today's culture, and we have to accept that they will show up in movies.

reviews.review_title: Once you get past the obvious....
reviews.content:
This movie is a: a shameless money-making ploy for kids with phones and, b: a gigantic corporate advertising vehicle.However, once you get past that, there is actually some fun to be had. Yes, I went easy on it because it's a kid's movie but really, so is "The Master of Disguise" ,and this is leagues better than that.
Gene is actually kind of a compelling character in some ways. James Corden's character provides some pretty good humor for what we're dealing with here. In the end, Gene finds himself, and gets the girl, or at least the girl emoji. This is not before a few colorful and surprisingly interesting scenes. There is even a little bit of fun to be had for adults, probably for parents if they happen to be watching along with their kids. At one point the whole text-world is about to get deleted and a poo emoji starts punching a fan!
Some of it's a little hard to process in terms of relating to human-like emojis but I doubt the movie's target audience will care. The end does kind of contradict the premise of the movie to start with but really, I'm an adult, and I'm overthinking this. If you don't have access to this or don't want to watch it first, take it from me, long story short: it's a decent kid's movie.

I don't understand why everyone hates it so much. I just took it for what it was. It was a cute little story. I think people were expecting like Sausage Party which I couldn't even finish watching but I digress. I could watch this movie over again. It was kind of funny too.

reviews.review_title: It's not the worst movie ever, but I do agree with the general consensuses..
reviews.content: The Emoji Movie is not the worst movie ever. Yes this movies has its limitations in a lot of places, and honestly, I can't think of another movie made blatantly based on the assumption, "KIDS WILL WATCH ANYTHING!" mentality but it's not the worst. I've heard people say, "It's just a kids movie! Were you really expecting a masterpiece out of an emoji?"First off, animated movies have broken our expectations before. If you can make a masterpiece out of; a rat who wants to be a chef (Ratatouille), a penguin who can surf (Surf's up), oh and A PANDA WHO WANTS TO DO MARTIAL ARTS (Kung Fu Panda), you can make a good movie out of just about anything, regardless of who made it. Also, the "It's just a kids movie" is just the laziest excuse ever. I personally think that children deserve good movies too, and not just a distraction to gawk and laugh at. The movies I mentioned above can actually be enjoyable for people other than 5 year old's. And no, lovely animation and a 'good message' isn't enough anymore.I will say a few positives, like the animation is amazing, a few jokes got a guilty smile out of me, and I admire Jailbreak's line: "How can you be number one, if there are no other numbers?" So, one or two things to enjoy, but just skip it, and show your kids a better movie.

reviews.review_title: A truly underrated feel good film about persuing your dreams and accepting yourself, with lots of fun along the way!
reviews.content: I don't understand all the poor reviews, this film was creative and innovative from a new perspective: building a whole world around a small tech feature

Well, not as bad as the ratings and reviews shown here. It was pretty enjoying to me. I just wished the main conflict was not about how an emoji should be because emoji was just an emoji. It has to be smile emoji, meh emoji, etc and not a "multi-talented" emoji. You know, like Monster Inc movie where one of the main conflicts was about who could scare kids the most.
Watched this with a bus full of 8 year olds. Thank you God for the experience of a lifetime and have a good day.

Bad humor, Bad plot, and even bad animaton. If I were the CEO of Sony (the creators of the emoji movie), I would demote whoever suggested the idea. If I could describe this movie with one word I would call it CRAP.

reviews.review_title: This can't possible contain spoilers because I left 5 minutes in(I actually didn't watch it) ;-)
reviews.content: Bringin back 2010 in an absolute catastrophy of a movie

It's weird that the movie's main character is the Meh Emoji, and so so fitting. It's a pretty formulated movie about an emoji who does not just want to be one thing and goes on a journey though a kid's phone to prevent from getting deleted for being able to do multiple faces. The movie is somewhat satire on social media apps and how we communicate with one another these days ( I did like one part in which a teacher is teaching kids about hieroglyphics, the original emojis). All the big names like face book and Instagram make an appearance in the film. There were a few big laughs in the movie. It's one of those things where there making fun of one of the apps and if you use that app or understand how it's used than it will give you a chuckle, but man it's so funny how the film is as lackluster as the emoji they picked as the main character. Hollywood needs some new ideas.http://cinemagardens.com

reviews.review_title: If i could rate 0 i would
reviews.content: Oh boy what do i even say...i knew this movie would be like every other movie but my god i didn't think it would be so bad from immature jokes to just plain aggravation this movie is everything bad that it could have possibly been. If you are somebody who likes animation but doesn't care about 1:Story 2:Character 3:Entertaining and pretty much anything else than this movie is for you. Overall this movie is bad and should have never been created.

reviews.review_title: Enjoyable if you haven't seen much animated films
reviews.content: I expected a lot worse than what I saw here and because of that, I was able to enjoy a lot of it but nonetheless, it is awful. The plot is a generic ripoff of a number of animated films and the animation could have been a lot better, although it was clear from some scenes that it wasn't the animators but the director who didn't have much idea on what to do. There were a lot of moments which could have come out better if someone with a little more creativity worked behind this. The worst part is that some kids are gonna like it because they are uninitiated with better films and would grow up thinking this to be a classic with a nostalgia clouding their judgement even when they grow up.

This movie is harmless and fun for kids. My friends and I ironically saw this on the opening night at our locally theatre, and shockingly enough, we liked it! Don't watch expecting a Pixar quality movie, this is for kids and has some okay jokes that might make you laugh out loud. This movie had so much bad hype, people wanted to hate it so they did, but If you look past it all it's a throwaway harmless movie that shouldn't effect you. 
6/10

I actually kind of liked this movie. I can't say it's the new Shrek or something like that, but it was kind of nice. The story was clear and easy to understand. It's child-safe and it has some easter eggs in it. Par example: the chase in Shrek with that dragon that gets entangled in her own chains. I always enjoy it when people put easter eggs like that in their movie. So this is my conclusion: if you're ill and too tired to watch more complicated movies, this is kind of nice. Just keep a vomit bucket with you for during the ending scene. That scene was just too sweet.

reviews.review_title: Not the worst but still bad.
reviews.content: This movie is a joke. It is basically the lego movie, inside out and wreck it Ralph put together. It is literally an hour and a half of nothing but advertisement so do not watch it.
My granddaughters and I enjoyed it a lot! It's a kid movie so I'm not sure why the adult reviews are so harsh. Kids like it so that's all that matters.

reviews.review_title: It's god-awful, but I like it
reviews.content: The Emoji Movie is completely garbage, useless movie, designed to appeal to young children. It has terrible dialogue, most of the characters are boring and the plot is nonsensical. It is one of, if not the, worst movie I have ever seen. Even though it was such a terrible, god-awful film, I enjoyed it. It's got a certain charm to it that can only be achieved with a perfect storm of awful. Overall the movie fails outright. But just because it is bad, doesn't mean there's no fun to be had.

reviews.review_title: Did they just cancel Popeye Movie for... this?
reviews.content: This movie is a sad defecation on Sony Pictures. It is not just a sad defecation, it is a cashgrabbing dump on modern society. The Popeye Movie idea was cleverly put up, with great wordplay. But this... copypaste thing that copies Wreck-It Ralph and Lego Movie does not deserve to be reviewed, but I had to reluctantly do so. Gene is a meh emoji who does not have a filter, and he would make the wrong face. Gene = Emmet. One scene references Wreck-It Ralph. Hi-5 is the worst comic relief I've ever seen. Scrappy Doo? PFFT! What does he have against the Hi-5 Emoji? Jailbreak is Wyldstyle, and Smiley is Candy King or Lord Business. This film was so predictable and rotten, that it got a 1.4 on IMDb. This overtakes Adam Sandler's Jack and Jill as the 3rd worst movie in my Worst Movies List. On the plus side... The voice acting and animation is well done, but did they really have to make this bad?

Please don't watch this. Don't. I did. It was horrible, cringeful, just plain bad. Stay away from this movie, its poison in your veins and will leave you confused and angry. There is nothing redeeming in this movie, the jokes are horrible, the characters are just, boring. So boring, but its not The Room bad. Where its a bit funny. No this is just so bad its bad. There is no other way i can describe this level of bad.

Since its release in the summer of 2017, The Emoji movie seemed to have caused some sort of uproar from people causing many people to bash it and claiming it as the worst movie ever. A lot of that is highly overreactions. I had little to no expectations considering knowing how low its reviews were and knowing some about the basic of the film.With that said, although the movie is predictable and has a story which has been done before (lead character doesn't feel he belongs, so he sets out on a journey for some kind of redemption, meets a love interest along the way, ends in a happy ending), this is a children's film and for the younger crowd, and since they are familiar with these emojis, it's best not to take the film too serious.Overall, the emoji movie isn't nearly as bad as critics and people are claiming, no it's not a great masterpiece but the visuals and colors are nice looking, and there are some creative product placement. Also the film isn't nearly that long to completely drag on. This movie also made quite a lot at the box office ($217 million worldwide), so people must have enjoyed it to some degree.

Yep, you read the title, This movie is not worth it, This movie is about an odd-one-out emoji who's supposed to be meh that lives in a phone, ("ORIGINAL" IDEA) but makes a mistake and stuff, so he teams up with the Carpool Karaoke guy as your worst nightmare and a female emoji who is actually a princess this whole time (WRECK-IT RALPH DID IT FIRST) to make things right, Who wants to play "Spot the confusing product placement"? Basically, It is just the worst movie ever made in the century, heck, it even made "Foodfight!" look like "The Lion King"! It's a good thing I haven't seen this movie in theaters. But hey, That is just my opinion, So whatever you do, if there is one film, or many films, you need to watch, Please, PLEASE avoid this one. This movie is just one big Sir Patrick Stewart-fest.
I would rather drink 5 liters of spoiled milk instead of watching this movie again

Being a person who's outer expression is mostly 'meh', I will now be reminded of this movie whenever I'm aware of my outward indifference.
So now I feel like I've been forever tainted.Most people have slammed this as the worst thing to ever be made. That's harsh, even though I don't completely disagree. But I have seen worse things.
Still, why 2 stars and not 1 or less?
Well, 1 is for the voicing talent of T.J. Miller. I like the guy. He's what made the Silicon Valley series funny. And here, just hearing his voice, felt comforting. He's like that friend with the cool voice and the interesting stories (true or not) who can talk forever non-stop, but you don't mind because they fill up a void with life. They entertain when you can't be bothered to make an effort. The life of the party when you're happy to take a backseat and just chill whilst nursing your drink. He makes a good buddy.The other 1 star just has to go to the sheer audacity of making a movie about emojis in the first place.
What would Disney and Pixar writers from 20 years ago make of this? Even the writers of the dystopian Wall-E (2008) would have not predicted the dystopian direction of something like The Emoji Movie becoming a reality.
Still, the pitch to Sony (or Columbia Pictures) would have been easy enough.
'Emojis come in a variety of expressions,' they would say. 'So many of them. And each of them can be a different character. Then there's all the animals. And body parts. And objects. And... all the other things you can send in a text that isn't a letter. All of those are characters, so the world building is easy peasy.
At this point, Sony (or Columbia Pictures) are almost on board. 'But what about the story?' they'd say.
Well, for the producers, that would be the easiest part. Just take a bit of Inside Out (the behind-the-scenes universe) and a bit of Wreck-it-Ralph adventure, and there you have it. The same old rehashed story told from another perspective. They'd argue that kids and young teens would gobble it up. Seeing their favorite emojis up on the screen would be a thing they never knew they loved, up until that moment.
'Just think of all the stuffed and plastic emoji toys that could follow after the movie's success,' they'd say.It was a gutsy move. Especially that it was a move made by grown-up responsible adults. Serious people talked about this in conference meetings and studio discussions and writer/animator sessions.Maybe the whole thing was a dare between the producers and creators? See if they could get something like this green-lit? Because that type of boldness deserves some form of respect, surely.
(Nevertheless, Netflix would have happily payed for it anyway if Sony had said no. But Netflix is hardly a challenge in getting something through, so they wouldn't count).

This movie is so "bad" that, philosophically, it starts to make you question what makes a "bad" movie, and what the different types of bad are. This movie is probably bad in the worst way possible - it's empty and soulless. This isn't art. This isn't something that tried and missed it's mark. It's a manufactured product using a store-bought just-add-water story. It's the cinematic equivalent of a TV dinner. Now, TV dinners are edible but are they really nourishing? This movie isn't a "failure". The story is fine and complete. But it's soulless.

reviews.review_title: I'm not sure why it's rated so badly
reviews.content: This wasn't the best kids movie I've ever seen but it was entertaining and funny for the kids and adults alike. I've given it 6 stars, would've been 6.5 but IMDB doesn't go halves. Worth a watch if you need something easy :)

This movie was a mistake in all senses of the word. The animation was pretty good, I'll give it that, but the writing and quality control of the voice acting and screenplay was abysmal. The only benefit to this movie was the reaction of the internet.Sony Pictures Animation has fallen so, very, far.

reviews.review_title: I didn't think this movie is that bad.
reviews.content: Look, I ain't gonna listen to the critics bad-mouthing this movie because I've found it very entertaining. I think Gene Meh is adorable, alongside with Hi-5 and the indie chick emoji, Jailbreak, with the exceptions of the "Poop" emoji (with a bad taste in dialogue) and Smiley, who I personally think is a real b****. There are other badly criticized flicks I will agree by the critics with, like "Care Bears Movie II: A New Generation", "Tom and Jerry: the Movie", and my two worst nightmares, "The Cat in the Hat" and "Foodfight!".

*This review is based on the Spanish version and not the originalA film about the life of emojis may sound too absurd,but somehow the creators of this movie made it work. The Emoji movie is surprisingly fun and enjoyable for adults as well. Now, this is nowhere near being as good as a Pixar animation or something made by Disney, but I can honestly say this has a unique quality to it. I'm sure this will never be a classic or stand the test of time and that is ok. See it for what it is and have fun.

This review for The Emoji Movie is spoiler free* (1/5) "THE MOST IMPORTANT form of communication are emojis," narrates T.J. Miller's Gene towards the start of The Emoji Movie is just one of the messages that can be found throughout Sony Pictures' cash cow scheme to bring in more money from a bad movie, which of course with the title Emoji Movie what's more to expect? Yes, this is the worst animated feature of the year for mainly one reason is that animations can be seen as the most creative form of film, however the idea to have multiple facial expression as the protagonists is possibly the laziest from of creativity. The Emoji Movie opens with Gene a multi-expressional Emoji who can change his expression by the flick of his face; his quest is to be placed on the screen for his user. He lives with other Emojis in Textville a world filled with different faces and emotions. The plot is essentially that Gene is fired from Textville's message board called The Cube, so he sets out on a quest to become a normal Emoji. That's pretty much it. Is there more to having a multi-expressional Emoji who tries to become normal? Of course, because for that it would have to follow logic and, from the off there is no logic here. There are many references to other, better forms of communication which of course our characters travel through in order to get to Cloud through Dropbox it's a continuous spiral of references and piling bad puns which can be seen from a mile away and will have you shacking your head. At its best the animation colourful (though mostly yellow) and brings all these emojis to full colour – even this deviates between cheap rubbery animation techniques to knock-off Pixar. There is even a short before the film based on Sony's own Hotel Transylvania in a vague attempt to follow Pixar success. In terms of cast, choosing T.J. Miller as Gene isn't a bad choice as he delivers some perhaps extended charm to the feature. With him there is a wide variety of different voices to hear firstly there's, Smiler (Maya Rudolph), Jailbreak (Anna Faris) a hacker, Hi-5 (James Corden), Mel Meh (Steven Wright),and finally there's Poop (Patrick Stewart) – though these are clever casting choices they are given nothing funny to say, in fact most of the things they do say is piled on by bad puns – "I'm always smiling" Smiler says at one point which makes this become lazy and incoherent to follow (in case you tried). In short, The Emoji Movie is a faithless; a zestless boilerplate animation which fails in many accesses of its audience and deserves a huge thumb down. VERDICT: An annoying, zestless, tasteless and boring animation which comes with lazy themes and tropes, abandon all hope ye who enter here.

reviews.review_title: The example for "I've Seen Worse, much much MUCH worse!"
reviews.content: Ever wonder what would happen if somebody made a movie in which every cliché ever was used with nothing original being added? No? Well what if I told you there was a movie that made Jaws 4: The Revenge look like Alien or made the Room look like The Godfather? That movie isn't even on par with the awful disgrace to humanity that is the Emoji movie. This is not even close to being a good movie. If you can even call it a movie, it's the worst movie ever made! And there have been lots of bad animated films, hell lots of films in general, what is this the year 2017. But I think this one takes the awful cake made out of rotten eggs made out of smartphone emoji's. It's a rip off of The Lego Movie, Inside Out, and Wreck it Ralph all at once, and it is beyond any doubt the worst thing that Sony ever created. Worse than Hotel Transylvania, worse than Open Season, worse than the Smurfs reboot, worse than the Annie remake, worse than Battlefield Los Angeles, worse than After Earth, worse than Pixels, worse than Ghostbusters 2016. There may be films that are worse in plot like Home on the Range, worse aesthetically like Shark Tale, or worse character wise like Norm of the North. But in terms of overall quality, this is the all time low! Stay away! Stay away as far as possible! THE ABSOLUTE ONLY THING THIS MOVIE CAN DO IS MAKE YOU APPRECIATE OTHER MEDIA! If you disregard my previous advice and watch this film anyway, and somehow manage to sit through it, don't expect a gold medal. You just wasted your time, and I feel bad for you. Likewise if you got this warning too late, once again you have my condolences, especially if you're on the younger side. BUT, you will be able to actively appreciate other media. You'll look at Jurassic World the way you see King Kong, you'll see Sword Art Online the way you see The Last Airbender (the TV series), and you'll see Brave the way you see Toy Story! Go watch any of those before you see this movie, but if you ignore my advice, whenever you watch another form of media at least you'll be able to say without a doubt, "I've seen a lot worse."

reviews.review_title: Funny for all the wrong reasons
reviews.content: The emoji movie is a very rare type of movies that are, so bad you can watch them twice and still have a good laugh. If i could vote 0 I would. The movie itself is meh. Actually it's worst as meh. I don't even know why Sony made one in the first place. This movie is worse than world war 1 and the room, and thats a hard act to follow. If they decide to make an emoji movie 2, then I quit. The idea and movie itself is meh, actually it's worse than meh, it's abysmal.

reviews.review_title: A movie for the kids, but not for the older members of the audience...
reviews.content: The Emoji Movie is a film that can only be described for me as a "kiddie-flick", meaning it will really entertain the kids and make them love it, but for most adults, some might find it mediocre, enjoyable, or just simply annoying. In all other words, your kids will love it. You probably won't.

reviews.review_title: This movie was not epic enough
reviews.content: I was expecting there to be a moral to the film, as there were many instances of social media interfering with the main human character Alex's relationships. I thought he was gonna realize that friends are more important than "fans" (which is how the movie put it), but that didn't happen. I would've accepted anything else in comparison to what I got. The emojis ended up improving his social life somehow, which doesn't make sense (Alex's crush takes a liking to him because he sent her an emoji, her reasoning being that he's more expressive with his emotions than other guys. Through emojis.) and contradicts what emojis were made out to be by the film itself: nuisances to actual social lives.I found no redeeming qualities. The fact it relies on product placement to progress the story. The terribly unoriginal and lazily minimalistic character designs. To add insult to injury, the cheap animation and bare minimum of a story pair well with the unfunny performances the film provided, especially the character of Hi-5, who was one of the worst comic relief characters I've ever seen or heard in a film, ever.In addition, the Jailbreak emoji did almost nothing to aid multi-expression emoji Gene on his journey, only acting as his unnecessary love interest. The reveal that she's actually a princess emoji is not in the least surprising, as she implies it multiple times prior to the reveal, unsubtly.Also, hearing T. J. Miller proudly exclaim "I'm an emoji" made me wanna die.

I can't believe how much this movie is getting slammed. The awfulness of this film is like a plague. I was released just this past weekend and already its getting massive backlash. So, I had to see what the fuss was about. And I've got to say, its pretty embarrassing that we live in a world where something like this exists. I am a huge fan of animated films and I think they can appeal to any demographic. But this movie gives the business a bad rep. Hopefully other studios will see this disaster and try their best to avoid films like this. Sony Pictures is in a landslide with this one and its going to take something drastic to recover from this. I just don't see them making many more films after this. Who knows? Maybe the film's 50 million dollar budget will save it. But money aside, this is without a doubt an abomination. I'm not even going to get into the issues because it will take all day to write it. If you want to take a chance to see for yourself, go ahead. But don't say I or the tons of other critics didn't warn you. This is a film for the ages, and not in a good way. Oh yeah, Patrick Stewart voices a piece of poop. Can't believe I have to say that. Stewart deserves better. Here are the grades. Characters: F, Animation: A, Story: F, Screenplay: F, Overall: F

I know I'm a little late to writing a review for this movie but I just had to, after hearing how bad It Is and trailers didn't help one bit, I just had to see It and I didn't plan to, even the Nut Job 2 looked more funny then this... but that's not saying much.A little story before hand that's more funnier then the movie It's self, before It started me and my friend went to get our tickets by using a Unlimited card (Instead of paying my own money Instead thank god..), we go Into a screening, I sit down, put my snack and drink down and It was empty, just how I wanted It.But then the trailers started and were rated 15, which was strange because the film was rated PG (even though It was shown U on the BFFC Ident for some reason..) so I go outside and wait for my friend to come back, she does come back and I told her we might be at the wrong screening, so I look at the ticket and I was right we were at the wrong one, so we go Into the right one, I took a deep breathe before I went In and as I went In there was other people, not slit only like a group, like maybe three adults and three kids, so as film went on they were laughing with the movie, the puns the y'know "Unfunny" stuff.So I sat down and watched the film and..... yeah, It's terrible, like HOLY F**KING S**T! It's terrible and I'm not just saying that or agreeing It's true, where do I begin?, oh let's start with the concept which as expected copies Disney's Wreck-It Ralph, Pixar's Inside Out and a bit of LEGO Movie In there, three really great films that are WAY better then this... this! GARBAGE!.Another Issue Is the plot, characters and humour, why all In one?, because they are all same like In most kids movies, bland and very mean-spirited characters, generic plot and hit or miss humour and this movie does exactly that, I'll admit I did get a couple of chuckles out of this movie, coming from HI-5 and that's about It, that's properly the closest to be funny, everything else Is just cringey, unfunny and insulting, even the moral of being yourself really makes It more obviously cringey that It completely ripoff Inside Out!.The only plots that there Is are Gene's parents going out of Textroplis to look for him and main villain Smiler going on about deleting Gene and they are really pointless and predicable that they might as well remove It entirely, the characters also got through a lot of apps like YouTube, Facebook even the Twitter bird Is a character, they even show ApplePen on YouTube... and Gene says hashtag.. I'm not kidding, these people must be so obsessed with putting lots of advertising In their own movie about Emojis!... good grief..I guess the only tolerable that I like Is the animation, It's colorful, looks nice and well designed, well on the humans, the Emojis just look basic and dull, maybe If all of the problems I mentioned were fixed In a YouTube series about Emojis, I would of been fine with that, but to be released AS A MOVIE?! IN CINEMAS?! THIS IS LITTERLY CANCER!.So yeah the Emoji Movie SUCKS!, It's dull, unfunny, clichéd, characters are a-holes, the idea and moral rips off other successful movies and the concept makes no sense, the animation Is okay and Hi-5 did me chuckle a couple of times, even the voice acting from talented people like TJ Miller, James Corden, Anna Farris and even Patrick Stewart feel wasted on this... piece of s**t!, jus... just don't see guys, they are better kids films out there to watch like Cars 3, Despicble Me 3 and Captain Underpants which I think are stilling In cinemas at this point.I wish to forget this movie entirely, It's worse then Norm of the North! and Ice Age: Collision Course!, yes I just said that Norm of the North was averagely bad and Ice Age 5'has some good things In It.As expected I'm giving this cancerous movie 0/10, do I need to explain why?

reviews.review_title: Forcing someone to watch this is inhumane
reviews.content:
I got so bored while watching it that while it was still playing i made this IMDb account just to rate it 1 star. This movie is the reason why IMDb needs to add a 0 star rating.
There has been an experiment in which a person is shocked when he touches a button, says that he's never going to touch it, then he gets put in a room with the button and they get so bored that they touch the button multiple times just because they have nothing better to do.
Now, if they repeat this experiment but this time they replace the electric shock and the button with the Emoji Movie, it's going to bring in media attention and lawsuits because it's unethical to lock up a person in the same room as this horrendous movie.

It's no surprise to me that, in today's world, The Emoji Movie is a film that actually exists. Emojis are everywhere thanks to the dependence of smartphones to communicate and it won't be long until it overtakes Chinese, Spanish and English as the most common spoken language in the world. That's not even possible by the way but they'll find a way.Gene (T. J. Miller), a multi-expressional emoji, sets out on a journey to become a normal emoji. There's a little bit more to the plot however, it's not even worth delving further into what this is actually about.Anyone who's ever used a smartphone will be able to tell you that there can be some fun had in using emojis to express yourself, whether it be in an innocent or rude manner. Is it fun to sit through a ninety-minute film about emojis though? The answer is a resounding no.The Emoji Movie is just an excuse for blatant product placement and a chance to make incredibly irrelevant references to popular culture, the Pen-Pineapple-Apple-Pen song playing as they enter the YouTube app making me want to scream in anger. It's full of insanely annoying characters too, James Corden's Hi-5 being like a turd that just won't flush. You think he's gone but then he makes a very unwanted return.The product as a whole, whether it be the unimaginative animation or the uninspired vocal performances, is void of any likability factor and the fact that I didn't hear one child laugh throughout speaks volumes. Animated films have come on leaps and bounds when it comes to conveying a message to the audience, but not The Emoji Movie. One of the only messages I took from this film was that boys should talk to girls via emojis prior to any form of human interaction. F**k my life.The Emoji Movie is as bad as I thought it'd be and then some. Avoid at all costs.

*** This movie has gender politics *** Despite the shocking ratings for this movie, it's actually better than the other children's release at the moment (which also suffers from gender politics), the Ninjago Movie. Who is pushing sexism on young children? Why is it always one sided sexism? The Ninjago movie lacked heart. The Emoji movie has heart (especially due to T. J. Miller's performance). You end up liking most of the characters. However, the story is very predictable and leaves little to the imagination. This is what separates this movie from a Pixar movie. Pixar movies have heart and brains.If you really have to pick a movie for the holiday season for your children, get out an old movie so you don't have to deal with the gender politics ("why are men always taking credit for what women do" type of garbage). If you're desperate for a cinema experience, pick the Emoji movie.

This is the first movie I can bet $10000 on how it would end just after 5 minutes into the plot. And there is ABSOLUTELY no highlight point throughout the 80 minutes of bore. I would have completely fallen asleep within 20 minutes if I was not the only adult accompanying my girl.It is absolutely fitting that the main character is called Meh. All conversations are Meh. Jokes are meh. Story lines are meh. I understand our reliance on, or addiction to, digital gadgets is somewhat inevitable in our lives, but PLEASE! Not everyone is a freaking teenager trying to live through his life by texting. With emoji! Words of wisdom: wait for reviews of movie before buying your tickets.

reviews.review_title: This is why humanity has fallen.
reviews.content: Since "Toy Story" became an enormous box- office hit and a beloved modern masterpiece by giving audiences an inspired look at what ordinary toys do when their owners aren't around, Hollywood has been striving to repeat that seemingly simple formula with a number of animated films that have offered viewers a privileged glimpse at the heretofore unseen existence of everything from the shelves of a grocery store (the execrable "Foodfight!") to the psyche of a young girl (the stunning "Inside Out"). Now comes "The Emoji Movie," a film that dares to ask "What goes on in the magical worlds contained within our cell phones?," a notion that I do not think that anyone has ever pondered for any amount of time outside of those stuck in a focus group at Sony Animation. That is only the first of many problems with this film, a work so completely devoid of wit, style, intelligence or basic entertainment value that it makes that movie based on the Angry Birds app seem like a pure artistic statement by comparison.The extremely dubious conceit of "The Emoji Movie" is that hidden within the messaging app in our phones is a teeming metropolis known as Textopolis, where all of the emojis live and wait to be called upon by their owners to say what mere words cannot. All emojis are supposed to have only one facial expression but Gene (T.J. Miller), who is supposed to be a "meh" like his parents (Steven Wright and Jennifer Coolidge), is just so darn exuberant that he is unable to stick with just one expression. This becomes a problem when his phone's owner, a 14-year-old boy named Alex struggling to reach out to the girl that he likes, selects Gene for a text he is sending to her—Gene chokes at the last second and coughs up so many expressions that it is impossible to understand what he is supposed to represent. Discovering his secret and fearing what it could mean for everyone if one emoji seems to be malfunctioning, Smiler (Maya Rudolph), the always-grinning leader of Textopolis, decides to have Gene wiped out for good. Gene manages to escape Smiler's clutches and with the help of another outcast emoji, the once-popular Hi-5 (James Corden), he hits upon a plan to have himself reprogrammed to show only one expression so that he can finally fit in. The only emoji who can do this for him is master hacker Jailbreak (Anna Faris), who agrees to help him if he will come with her on a journey to the fabled Cloud, where his ability to change expressions could help her get past the impenetrable firewall protecting it. Their journey across the phone takes the three to a number of different apps and along the way, they learn valuable lessons about Being Yourself and Friendship and the like while being pursued by Smiler's troops, who have all been outfitted with illegal upgrades to make them extra-powerful. To make matters worse, Alex, having grown increasingly annoyed by the glitches inadvertently caused by Gene's journey, has made an appointment to have his phone and everything contained within completely erased.So what wonders lie just beneath our touch screens, anyway? Based on the evidence put forth by "The Emoji Movie," it is a combination of product placement and corporate synergy. Textopolis itself is an indifferently conceived and executed cityscape populated by any number of familiar emojis, the most famous of which is presumably Poop, who is voiced by none other than Sir Patrick Stewart in one of his less dignified gigs. Once we get outside the walls of Textopolis, we are essentially placed into a series of mini-ads for well- known apps that range from brief detours to the lands of Facebook and YouTube to extended commercials for the Candy Crush and Just Dance games. Since nothing of import goes on during these scenes (or any others, for that matter), I found myself speculating on which ones spent the most money to appear in the film based on the length of their exposure and the praise that they receive from the characters. Based on the available evidence, Dropbox must have been the big spender here—not only is it the all-important gateway to the Cloud but the characters manage to safely hide out from the bad guys there because, and I quote, "they are illegal malware and this app is secure." Then again, my guess is that the film could have gone into profit solely from taking money from companies eager to keep their apps as far away from this as possible.

Many kids value more IMPORTANT things than phones and screens, like their education and their family. That stereotype is an insult to kids, and the kids who see that will not want to watch this. The plot and characters were very, very bland, (it IS about EMOJIS, after all), and the dialogue is just plain bad. This movie has been stuck in my head ever since I made the terrible mistake seeing this in theaters a few years ago. This movie is annoying and pointless. It has poor storytelling and is a mix of cliches from other movies. It's nothing but a cash grab advertisement and one of Sony's biggest mistakes yet.I haven't watched this for a long time, and I'm grateful. For all you lucky people who haven't seen this stupidity, then DON'T. The Emoji Movie is not worth your time at all. Don't even bother renting it.

I guess it had to happen, we live in a time now where nothing is sacred, nothing is safe from being milked dry, and anything is free game. We've seen it all from various obscure choices in the video game archives; to Barbie to 'Thomas the Tank Engine' to board games and to Lego. They will make a movie out of bloody anything given half a chance. I'm half expecting an animated movie about the world of marbles to roll along anytime soon (yes I'm proud of that pun).I think its fair to say I wasn't expecting anything much from this movie, if anything I only saw it out of pure morbid curiosity. I was simply intrigued at how they could construct a narrative around some mobile phone app icons. And my God do they try their best here! They really stretch and reach and twist that thin ass plot as best they can. Does it work? Not really no, but kudos for trying.I mean I can't deny there are some nice little touches here, its not all terrible. The emoji's live inside a phone (duh) which is owned by a young boy named Alex. Said boy is going through the usual pre- pubescent angst with girls and whatnot and of course being young he uses his phone a lot. Within the phone the emoji's dwell in the city of Textopolis (I like it), their daily job is to produce their emoticon or expression on demand (when Alex uses it). Gene is a 'meh' emoji but he can also make other expressions which is looked upon as freakish, or like having a rare disease. When Gene gets his chance to be used by Alex he has a nervous breakdown and fudges it up. He then finds himself listed for deletion because he is now deemed a malfunction. Gene must now flee the city with another has- been emoji to help him find a hacker to hopefully get himself fixed.So the plot is pretty much the same old sh*t we've many times before. The protagonist must go on the run to evade the antagonist and her henchmen (henchemoji's). Along the way the protagonist meets new friends that are considered losers basically; and in the end after numerous scrapes they all discover themselves and make friends (whilst saving the day). Its a standard plot mapped on top of this emoji concept. Despite that its still flippin' convoluted though, the nonsense they set up to explain how emoji's are used on a phone. Its kinda treated like a gameshow scenario where talented, experienced and obviously popular emoji's are used regularly (almost like a sports team). But if an emoji shows good promise or whatever then they get the chance to be 'promoted' onto the phones main app screen. It sounds ridiculous because it basically is. Then all the emoji's that aren't used anymore get lumped into a loser lounge type scenario. Very predictable but also somewhat daft as I'm sure most emoji's actually get used a fair bit the world over.Call me stupid but one of the main fun things about this movie was spotting all the different emoji's (sad I know). And sure enough they're all here, right down to the national flags. I quite like how the old emoticons are presented as old age pensioners, umm...that's about as clever as it gets really. Aside from that the entire movie plays out like a long TV advert for various smart phone apps like 'Twitter', 'Candy Crush', 'Just Dance' etc...The movie also uses every flippin' bit of computer jargon it can muster, in a very predictable and cringeworthy fashion. For instance, pirating is represented by...yep...pirates. A Trojan horse is...umm...a big horse. A firewall is a big fiery wall (ugh!!!), and a virus is a sick looking electronic bacteria (flip me!). Add to that a whole bunch of nauseating pop songs, modern trendy teen lingo, various brands and voilà! The sidekick characters bland and unfunny (hi-five and a princess), again totally predictable. Alex decides to completely wipe his phone when a few apps play up, why not just uninstall them? When the phone is almost wiped Alex stops because of an unusual emoji?? (Gene pulling a stupid face). This emoji is then sent to the girl he has a crush on and she instantly likes him because of that?? Most of the emoji's in Textopolis are erased during this process, but they all come back perfectly OK when the phone is rebooted? No side affects from that?Overall the movie certainly isn't as bad as I thought it was gonna be (but its still quite bad). There are some kernels of a good idea hidden away within, the odd sparse highlight. But again overall its still very very basic, bland, uninspiring, unfunny, and it doesn't even look that great really. This was always gonna be an uphill battle simply because what the hell can you do with emoji's?? I stand by my kudos to all involved for actually managing to produce something that isn't a complete train wreck, but at the end of the day I think we can all agree with was a complete waste of time and money. Heck the aim seems to be to push young kids towards their phones more than ever. As if youngsters need that kind of encouragement these days.3.5/10

reviews.review_title: Do not see this movie. It hurts to watch even ironically
reviews.content: This movie is both boring, and rage inducing at the same time. I, with no exaggeration, almost attempted suicide for the fifth time in the past year. If you have a history of suicide, I wouldn't risk going to The Emoji Movie as it might trigger an episode. If you're a member of the target demographic for this film and are planning on going to see this movie, re evaluate your life then promptly proceed to donate whatever money you were going to pay for your tickets to charity and take your family out for dinner at a nice restaurant

Having been released in the U.S. a few months ago to a critical mauling, I intended to avoid this animated abomination at all costs. My 7 y.o. daughter, however, had other ideas. Following Gene (T.J. Miller), a malfunctioning 'meh' emoji who can't control his vast range of emotions, we enter the working world of a smartphone whereby every tap of the screen requires a functioning digital population to make it happen. In a universe where everyone (everything?) has its place, Gene is ridiculed for his expressiveness and, after sending out the wrong emoji for his user (Alex, a teenage boy in the midst of his first romance), must go on the run from the delete-happy Smiler (Maya Rudolph). Ostensibly an adventure comedy, there is neither enough thrills to make it exciting or enough laughs to make it amusing; ironically falling into a zone of complete meh-ness. The jokes about twitter, internet trolls and the controlling nature of smartphones in modern society would have been astute a few years ago, in 2017 they're already out-dated and tired. And the target audience for this film wont understand them anyway. Thankfully there are some hilarious visual gags like the poop emoji exiting the toilet oh wait, nope, even that is old and boring, barely getting a titter from the packed cinema of kids (and parents regretting their choice) ready to laugh at just about anything. The animation is unsurprisingly bright and James Corden's sidekick Hi-5 adds a smidge of delight, however The Emoji Movie ultimately has less flavour and value-for-money than the watered-down soft drink and over-priced popcorn from the cinema's candy bar.

reviews.review_title: Quite possibly the worst animated movie I have ever seen.
reviews.content: When I first saw the trailer in May, I instantly knew the creation of this garbage was a mistake. Now I know I was correct. The characters are bland, the story is cliché, and the villain is basically like every other cliché villain. The entire movie just felt like a Wreck It Ralph rip off with emojis instead of popular video game characters. The jokes were not funny at all and there was WAY to much toilet humor in this that even a 7 year old kid who likes toilet humor would be annoyed by it. They listed this movie as "comedy" even though literally nobody laughed in the theater I was watching it in, not even some kids. Parents, spare your children from wasting 86 minutes of their life and go do something else with that time. This movie deserves to become a box office bomb and is not worth watching.

Ummm... a lot of people are just reacting on an emotional level to how awful the movie was. I also love all the sarcastic "loved it" reviews. Hilarious! But I'll try to explain exactly why it is...what it is... ***may contain spoilers****the kids begged me to take them to this movie. I hadn't heard of it. I went into this movie completely blind. Umm.... 1. The actual animation was good. Some of the imagery was well crafted...2. The "plot" was very unclear. Mixed messages...at first it sounds anti-tech, even sort of shaming society for being so addicted to their phones, but the whole movie is pretty much just one big product placement.It never explained how or why **SPOILER!** going to "the cloud" would restore High 5's popularity3. The extremely glazed over blink-and-you'll-miss-it scenes of the "real world" high school...why even bother to include it? Seemed like an after thought. Very VERY badly handled. And why have a dramatic 4 hour count down clock when it isn't mentioned again, and the tech appointment is changed in the end anyway?4. The other emojis made fun of Gene (names weren't memorable) because he has other emotions. Why? This was never clearly established, just vaguely referenced.5. There is something really wrong and inconsistent about the timing and pacing, and distances in the movie...can't quite put my finger on it. Relationships are formed too quickly between strangers. Gene and I-didn't't-bother-to-learn-her-name character have to travel all the way across the phone to rescue High-5 but when the villainous drone chases them around, the distance seems off. Am I wrong? 6. I got a few random chuckles here and there, but several hours later, I can't seem to recall any actual jokes...I think this movie tried to shoe-horn in a really corny introspective look at the inner working of...phones? Not having an "every man for himself" attitude? I'm starting to ramble and get angry now; my cue to stop typing. The little kids enjoyed the colourful moving graphics of this otherwise completely forgettable phone commercial.
People tend to forget that this is a kids movie! If my son likes it, am happy
I would rather break all my Jones in my boy than watch this horror movie i hate it
It's not the best movie ever, but it's enjoyable. I'd give it 7/10 but I hate seeing a low overall rating so 10/10.

I think people are being a bit harsh. :) is it my new favorite movie, no. It had a consecutive cute storyline At the end, a happy ending which made my kids happy. Graphically, it was well done. There were a few one liners that I even found funny. It was informative on technology terminology, which, shocked the heck out of me that it was included. Kudos to that. reviews.review_title: The animation was good, but everything else was a bore.
reviews.content: This could have been something enjoyable, but it fails to generate any interest. T.J. Miller I always find entertaining, but his voice over character is not giving much of any interest, neither does any of the animated characters. You really don't get infested into there doing. Trying to hard to be another Wreck-it Ralph(2012), and you can see how hard it was trying.Now the animation is pretty to look at, showing life inside an IPhone. But if that's all the movie has going for it. Only children can be forgiving of this, but adults not so much.

The Emoji movie its a big joke in the internet, I wish it was just that, an ironic joke made to satirize Hollywood's worst aspects, but no, The Emoji movie is a real movie, and while cash grabs have been present in the past this one got an incredible amount of attention, I guess people just needed something to laugh at seeing how absurd the concept is.I was really annoyed by this movie, every other line was painfully unfunny, there is not one original aspect in it, it rips off many elements from different animated films but doesn't know why they worked, so just decides to copy for no real reason. Every awful cliché from almost any other animated movie is present here, even clichés that could be considered the weakest parts of good animated films, at least those movies had other redeeming qualities, this one lacks any kind of positive aspect.I do believe that this is the worst of Hollywood, the cynical product placement (The whole movie is one), the awful politics it tries to shove down people's throats, the predictable story, the usual character archetypes we see every time and the evident disconnect it has from its target audience. I don't hate Hollywod but this is one movie not even I would defend.

I saw "The Emoji Movie", starring the voices of T.J. Miller-Silicon Valley_tv, Deadpool; James Corden-Into the Woods, The Three Musketeers_2011; Anna Faris-Mom_tv, The House Bunny and Maya Rudolph- SNL_tv, Bridesmaids.I try to keep an open mind on movies because I know that people have different likes and dislikes and every movie is not for everyone. But, I just can not decide who this movie is aimed at. It's animated, so that usually means small kids. The subject matter is about emojis in smartphones, so you would think maybe older teens and adults. There are a lot of poopy jokes, usually with or about the poop emoji, so that goes back to the younger audience. I don't know, maybe they were just trying to cover all their bases and try to have something for everybody. Whatever the case, it didn't work for me. The emoji world inside your smartphones is explored and you get to see how it works, at least according to this movie. T.J./Meh plays an emoji that has more than one emotion-all the other emojis have only one-so he goes on a quest to get himself straightened out. James/Hi-5 and Anna/Jailbreak come along to assist him. Maya/Smiler disapproves and tries to put a damper on their trip. There is a short film called 'The Puppy' that is shown before the movie-it has characters from the 'Hotel Transylvania' movies. There is also a scene right after the end credits start, but nothing at the very end. It's rated "PG" for some rude humor and has a running time of 1 hour & 26 minutes.It's not one that I would buy on DVD. I don't think I would rent it either. If you really want to see it, I'd wait until it comes to cable.

reviews.review_title: its clearly bad if even Sharknado has a better rating.
reviews.content: I only decided to watch this garbage because of its horrible rating. Wanted to see what the fuss was all about. Aside from the typical "hero's adventure" that has been played out in films over a thousand times, this movie in itself is basically one big commercial to sell apple, samsung phones and other products to kids. This is the end result when you have a generation of kids addicted to smart phones, you get bad movies designed purely to promote products, and not focus on actual original plot, dialogue, characters, etc. Waste of money, should've never bought that ticket. If you're reading this, don't buy their merchandise, or the tickets to movies like these. It only further promotes the production of garbage movies like this one.

My 4 year old boy liked the film as there are bright animations and he doesn't understand storylines yet. I usually love kids films but this is poor. Tried to be too clever but didn't deliver on comedy or plot. I don't understand how anyone would give this film 10. Must be paid!

Whatever you do, DO NOT SPEND YOUR MONEY ON THIS PIECE OF CRAP. You could be doing much better things with your life than paying to go see this pile of crap. And not to mention this is a rip off of Inside Out.

when i saw the movie i thought what a great idea that it has and really enjoyed the movie personally but when i came to IMDb i was expecting really high ratings but 2.7!really?i don't know why do people hate this film i found it really entertaining and by the way the whole emoji idea i really think that is awesome by still its one of the most hated movies that i don't really get it

reviews.review_title: Pound Shop Lego Movie but it really doesn't suck that hard.
reviews.content: Everyone keeps saying this movie is terrible but it's not that bad.I think anyone will admit that it's not exactly polished; a lot of the jokes are too in-your-face, there's an over abundance of puns and a lot of the dialogue is heavy and awkward but that doesn't mean it isn't fun.The inspiration apparently came from toy story and continues a tradition of compiling real pop culture references that we saw in Roger Rabbit, Food Fight and Wreck It Ralph though the movies actual narrative seems most indebted to the Lego movie with its themes of conformism and creativity of expression.I like the message even if it is kind of ham fisted, both our protagonist Gene and the female lead Jailbreak are likeable even if JailBreak is blatantly just Wyldestyle from the Lego Movie and James Cordon's High comic relief as High Five is maybe kind of annoying but that's more due to lame jokes than any intrinsic problem. I found the antagonist actually pretty creepy, as are all perpetually happy people.Ultimately I came away feeling warmly about the movie for it's rich, distinctive world, positive message and how it embodies an aspect of its time while tying it to a universal them even if it's not exactly subtle about it.

reviews.review_title: It's a Masterpiece Alright...A Masterpiece of 💩
reviews.content: This movie got one thing right with it's marketing, and that's that it's "not easy being meh." For that to happen, you need a few things: some effort, equal parts creative, and some semblance of a soul. Even if it's not enough, you at least tried, and the problem with this movie is that it doesn't give a care in the world.While the animation and voice acting is good enough, the rest of the movie doesn't just go downhill, it jumps of a twenty foot cliff into a gorge of spikes, rattle snakes, and lava, and the worst part is it could've been another Lego Movie, Wreck-It Ralph, and Inside Out but decides to prove everybody right instead. First of all, the story makes no sense. The story follows Gene, a "meh" emoji, as he, Hi-5, and Jailbreak, the "hacker emoji how happens to be a princess who can call the Twitter bird despite being mad at Gene and Hi-5 for asking, journey to the cloud where Gene will be able to be "meh." Get ready for some plot holes, folks, because you'll getting them. As you can already guess, Gene's parents are also "meh" emojis, however, Gene has a case of not sticking to one emotion, because he can feel them all, baby, and as you progress through the movie, you learn that his father, Mel, also had the same issue, yet he was able to control the emotions. So why didn't he help Gene during the years he was a father? Seriously, this "disorder" didn't crop up overnight, did it? And why was Gene allowed to work with people knowing he has this "disorder?" No one snitched? Anyway, as you can expect, Gene messes up on his first day, when he made the wrong face, causing Alex the Human to send the wrong emoji to his crush, Ms. InsertRandomNameHereBecauseICan'tRememberIfSheWasInTheMovieOrNot (it's actually Addie, but as interesting she is, that might as well be her name). Let's look at how the movies it tried to rip off handle humans. In the Lego Movie, we learn that the movie took place within a child's imagination, thus leading up to a heartwarming end when the father appears, Inside Out was about emotions within the human mind, which does affect the human in some ways, and Wreck-It Ralph at least had the decency to have the humans take a back seat when Fix-It Felix Jr. didn't properly due to Ralph's absence. Yes, they made the danger of being trashed, but you didn't see the human every few minutes, because to the humans, the video game cabinet was just getting old and was likely glitching out for that reason. Here though, we cut back and forth between Phone World and the Human World. I don't like these punk kids. They're so obsessed with their phones that they can't communicate without it, and it feels like I'm a political cartoon about phones. They also have no personality other than being cutouts, and whenever the emojis journey into an app, they mess with the phone itself, such as turning on Spotify, Candy Crush, and Just Dance, embarrassing Alex, and that's it. Speaking of those things, the product placement! Seriously, they are terrible. Not only do they say the name of the apps, but they also demonstrate how to play Just Dance and Candy Crush. You have better fun playing a tutorial level in a video game than what's basically the equivalent of YouTuber reminding you every five minutes that video is sponsored by Dollar Shave Club. It makes the movie so...soulless. Back to the story though, there are more things that don't make sense. For example, the trash can scene! Okay, if an app gets deleted, wouldn't the people inhabiting the app essentially be dead and not alive in the Memory Dump from Inside Out? Also, why are trolls and spam there? While they were in the piracy app Alex had, these two things are not baked into phones or the apps themselves. Trolls are people who rile others up by saying "mean" things for their own enjoyment, and spam is stored on a server. So, again, why are they here? Also, Alex decides to erase his phone, in what's really the longest end-of-the-world segment I've seen, and because Gene used his multiple personalities to save his world, Alex unplugs the phone while it's wiping and sends the emoji to Ms. WhoAreYouAgain. First of all, I'm sure that will corrupt data on the phone, and what makes Alex believe it wasn't a virus causing that? Again, he has a piracy app installed, disguised as the Dictionary app, so he would've right to assume such thing. They didn't even try to write a cohesive story, I think the out-of-touch big-wigs at Sony just wanted the forced product placement in it.Lastly, the characters are either vanilla or horrible. Examples are Hi-5 being a useless comic relief character until convenient, Hacker was a princess emoji that gets mad at Gene and Hi-5 for asking about whistling for birds, but she calls the Twitter bird anyway, and then there's Poop. This character is the reason Xavier went crazy in Logan, because he knew his actor took the easy job of just spouting a bunch of cringy poop jokes. Let's not forget Gene's dad, who , if you remember early in the review, is definitely parent of the year. The humans are also so boring with one-not personalities that they are really token characters, which is ironic since T.J. Miller, the voice of Jean, said that the movie had a "non-preachy feminist agenda." Please, do yourself a favor, and don't buy this movie. Don't even rent it. It's pretty much as bad as critics say it is. Only great thing about it was the Puppy short showed before it, and even that's on YouTube. Terrible movie!

reviews.review_title: The theater was crowded. Most People loved it despite the unjust extremely low ratings!.
reviews.content: The Emoji Movie is an excellent family-comedy movie if not the best from Sony Pictures.Hidden inside a smartphone, the bustling city of Textopolis is home to all emojis. Each emoji has only one facial expression, except for Gene, an exuberant emoji with multiple expressions. Determined to become "normal" like the other emojis, Gene enlists the help of his best friend Hi-5 and a notorious code breaker called Jailbreak. During their travels through the other apps, the three emojis discover a great danger that could threaten their phone's very existence.The theater was crowded with people (especially with children and their parents) who despite of the extremely low ratings and the bad reviews challenged and saw this entertaining and hilarious movie.

This movie is very much like the Disney Movie Inside Out. It involved no creativity whatsoever, because of its direct copy already successful movie Inside Out. Inside Out was a great movie for Disney Lovers, but then this bland remake came out, and i personally did not hate it, but did not enjoy it. It was OK. It was funny, although the jokes were very dirty. Young children will not understand but trust me adults will.
